editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE SIEGE OF Conſtantinople; A TRAGEDY Acted at the DUKE'S Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for Tho. Dring, at the Harrow over againſt the Inner-Temple Gate, Fleetſtreet, 1675.

div.head: PROLOGUE TO THE Siege of CONSTANTINOPLE.
div.l: POets and Duelliſts have the ſame Fate;
The braveſt man may be Ʋnfortunate:
You that reſolve to rayle at every Play,
Like pious men, worldly delights betray;
But if you will ne're pleaſe your ſelves you may.
So mirth is loſt, whilſt Fools diſpraiſe the Wine;
So Punk is dangerous be ſhe ne're ſo fine;

Thus ſubtly you 'gainſt all your joys
• ombine.
And warily by Arguments deſtroy
Thoſe very pleaſures which you ſhould enjoy:
Love Crown'd with Beauty and Succeſs can cloy.
Since at the beſt, your pleaſures are ſo few,
Make your ſelves any where you find'em new.
Be kind to us; and ſhe who faild to Night:
This Play, if prais'd, to morrow will invite
To meet you here, and your loſt time requite.
'Tis true, of late you juſtly have complain'd:
But thank your ſelves for what your Niceneſs gain'd;
When you before were ſuch high Critticks grown,
As if Wit only were by Cenſuring known
In praiſing, where 'tis due, Wit may be ſhown.
Severity does modeſt Authors fright
Self-prizing Fops with French Aſſurance write.
Thoſe who have Wit, like wary Gameſters fear
To hazard ſums, where but ſmall gains appear.
Whilſt empty Fools more briskly do expoſe
A Reputation, which they can not Loſe.

list.item:
Michael and
Lorenzo
The Chancellors Secretaries.

stage.hi: The Curtain drawn, diſcovers the Emperor, Thomazo, Theophilus, and Dorello on one ſide of a Table, the Cardinal, Chancellor, and Juſtiniano on the other, as at Councel; they ariſe and Exeunt, all with great reverence to the Emperor, except Thomazo and Dorello, who ſtay with him.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: SIr, they have carry'd it, and you agree,
It is by ſtrength of Argument & Reaſon;
Since they've the major part: yet I'le confeſs
I'm unconverted ſtill. This Rule of moſt
Appears to me ſtark madneſs; when that moſt
Are plainly prejudic'd, and led by faction,
In that caſe be they ne're ſo numerous,
All ſhould be counted nothing that they ſay,
For ſuch arn't Counſellors but Advocates,
And plead the cauſe of their own Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: But Brother ſay, how Princes like my ſelf,
That circumſcribe our actions by our Laws,
Can ſteer through all the Labyrinths of ſtate,
Shun Rocks and ſholes hid under ſinootheſt brows;
Meet and diſpiſe croſs Tides, and adverſe Winds;
That run and blow from ſeveral States-mens heads,
More various in their Changes far than thoſe
That puzzle able Pilotes on the Sea;
What way I ſay, but by theſe major Votes.
The true Magnetick needle of the States.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I'le allow Councels the perfect compaſs,
And major Votes in that the needle too.
But yet true Pilotes ſtill obſerve, the Cauſes
Oft make that vary from the polar Star,
Which when they ſee it does, let that point on,
They mind it not; but to obſerve its errour;
And what lov'd Headland it would guide unto;
And he that does not this, though he may make
One Voyage ſafe, muſt not be call'd a Pilate;
And this is your caſe now. Your this days councel
That raſhly have advis'd you Sir for Warr,
Have ſeveral private reaſons for that Vote,
Beſides the ſpecious ones they back it with.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: I cannot think it Sir: They're all wiſe-men,
And honeſt I believe; but were they not,
The grand concern this Councel has debated
Affects no leſs than all the Chriſtian world:
It is indeed, chuſe Chriſt or Mahomet,
Whoſe Law ſhall have the univerſal ſway,
And can a Chriſtian think that Chriſtians would
Give ſelfiſh Councels in their Saviours cauſe?
It is not charitable; it is not Brother
Now by my Crown you're too too poſitive,
And to no purpoſe neither. I'm reſolv'd—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Reſolv'd! on your own Ruine Sir I fear.
Chriſtian! Ay, that's the word; but Intereſt
Is the thing. That Damn'd Chancellor,
Romes Pentionary lately, now the Turks—

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Nay, may be both's Sir ſtill—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Moſt likely ſo.
H'has Province after Province, ſold the Realm
To this one Town almoſt; yet now forſooth
It is below our Honours to pay Tribute,
'Las that may make a Title; as if a Turk
Regarded any Title but Poſſeſſion;
Whilſt we were able, I ſtill preſt a War,
To keep the danger further from our Home,
Or drive it o're the Helleſpont again,
But then 'twas wiſely urg'd that my Ambition
Aym'd to be popular amongſt the Souldiers;
And this my Brothers jealouſie gave ear to;
As if a Brother that would ba • ely aim
At Empire by Diſloyalty and T •… on,
Would ſtand upon the way to compaſs it;
No, they miſtake my temper: All I ſeek,
Is bright unſully'd glory: I'd not be
Sole Monarch of the world by one baſe deed;
No, by my great and everlaſting hopes
I would not, my Dorello.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, they know that too well, they durſt not elſe
Play with the fire that might perhaps conſume 'em;
But 'tis their ſole Advantage you are honeſt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: And mine too; for the horrid pangs of guilt
That hourly torture them, and make 'em watch
The ſmall and buſie Whiſpers of the Crowd,
That buz in Courts, and make the thing call'd State
Ne're trouble me; I can undiſcompos'd
Receive ſome ill-taught, rugged man oth'Guard,
Rudely advancing to me from his place
To ask ſome Boon; when they at ſuch a time
Boggle, and ſtand amaz'd, expecting from him
The guilty, tho the well deſerved blow:
Their Dreams too I'm aſſur'd are all compos'd
Of Priſons, Axes, Daggers, and ſuddain Stabs;
Flight aſter Battle, or ſuch dreadful things,
When mine are made of ſweet and pleaſant walks,
Or elſe in Fields, where every ſtep I take,
I meet a Love, or joyful Victory.
And who would have the beſt part of his life,
Sweet ſleep ſo ſpoild, and loſe its name of reſt
By ills, whoſe ends obtain'd, are far leſs ſollid.
Come then; whilſt theſe bad men are faintly pleas'd
At this new Conqueſt o're th'Emperors ſoul,
And buſily are framing Keys and Cyphers
Falſely to give as falſe Intelligence;
"Let thou and I Dorello, free from care,
"To mirth and love our joyful minutes ſpare.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The Prince Thomazo reaſon ſtrongly urg'd
Againſt the War, and almoſt carry'd it;
He is a Prince of large and ſteady parts.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Ay Sir, the more we juſtly fear his power;
The Empire dreads not more its forraign Foes,
Then it does him at home; beſides, you ſee
How fiercely he propoſes joyning with
The Turks themſelves, rather than Weſtern Kings.
There's rooted in his ſoul the Antient hate
This Empire ſhew'd in the firſt holy War,
When they betray'd thoſe pious, valiant Knights,
Godfrey of Bulloign, Robert of Normandy,
And all the holy Cruciado'd Pilgrims,
That did accompany or follow them:
But let's no more of him; 'tis in his blood:
He hates both you and me, nay more unjuſtly
Envies the Deeds of our brave General,
Great Juſtiniano here, without whoſe help
This barb'rous Turk would quickly ſwallow us:
But do not be diſcourag'd Sir; you'l find
The Emperor your true and faithful Friend:
And me your Servant, conſtant to your merit.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: I do not doubt it Sir, nor fear his envy,
The Genowees my valiant Country-men,
Give them their pay, will fight in following me,
Till they and I perform ſuch mighty things,
Shall turn that envy into admiration.
Envy me! It ſtirs my rage me-thinks to hear it nam'd;
That any Greek, though of the greateſt blood,
Should ſo exalt his thoughts to envy me!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Anger's great, & noble, Sir: but ſpare it;
'Twas his Ambition to have had your place.
And whilſt that hope continu'd, he was ſtill
Preſſing for War, though now what man ſo Peaceful!
But fear him not; I'le watch the Emperour
That no affront ſhall e're be plac'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: On me affront! what Prince ſo hardy dares it?
Let him, that does it, though the Turks were here,
Here cloſe before our Walls, expect and ſind,
I'le turn this noble City to a ſlame,
And then like Zenophon from th'mid'ſt of Perſia,
I'd force my way through all the Turkiſh Camp,
And carry back my full four thouſand men
To Genoa again. This I would do Sir,
And on the leaſt Affront; by Heavens I would,
And tell the Emperor this, and ſo farewell;
You've heated me; I am not fit for Councel.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: How his brave Rage becomes him! 'Tis a Crime
In a great Souldier to be Ceremonious,
They that can laugh at Death on days of 's Triumph,
When circl'd round with Javelings, Spears, & Darts,
Arrows, Pikes, Partizans, and battle-Axes;
Mounted on Chariots, arm'd with murdering Sithes
Mowing down life it ſelf, in fields of men,
And prais'd by plaudits of the thundering Canon,
Almoſt annihilating thoſe they kill;
Thoſe that (I ſay) can meet Death thus and ſmile,
Need not concern themſelves in leſſer ſears.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: He's of that Country fame has ever courted,
For Arts and Armes, ſweet fertile Italy,
And without Arrogance, though I'm its native:
I'le ſay, no Nation under Heav'n comes near it
Now; though its Eagles wings are quite diſplum'd
For Souldiers, States-men, or Philoſophers.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: We need not travel thither Sir for proof
That the true Romane vertue is not ſpent,
Which civiliz'd the greateſt part oth' World,
Since in your ſelf we have full evidence,
Your Eminence ſpeaks Rome in her full Luſter.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Lord, your Complement I'le ſend to Rome,
It was I know deſign'd his Holineſs,
And I'le not rob him of it: 'Tis too high
For me his poor and humble Immitator.
But my Lord,
All I can ſay won't heighten his eſteem
Of your true Zeal, Wiſdom or Piety,
That under Heaven are like to have the glory
Of rooting up this long continu'd Schiſme,
And giving to St. Peters Chaire his due.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: 'Tis all the honour in this world I wiſh.

sp.speaker: Cardin.
sp.l: I'le not defer my Letters Sir for Rome,
That they may know your pious reſolution
Of ſtaking all againſt this barb'rous Turk.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I wiſh your Eminence, would preſs them hard
For ſpeedy ſuccors, and that his Holineſs
Would interpoſe his ſacred admonitions
To reconcile the Kings of France and England,
That private diſcords, lay'd by them aſide,
They might aſſiſt the general Chriſtian Cauſe:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I ſhall not fail it.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Letters writ, the Emperors expreſs
Shall wait upon Eminence for them.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Your Lordſhips faithful Servant.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Eminencies Creature.
Who waits there? Call Michael my new
Secretary to me!
Dance mighty Genius at my growing Fate,
All things as well as Thee conſpire my glory:
What a dull Earth-born crowd of groveling ſouls
Are all men but my ſelf, I yet could meet with:
This Cardinal, the Cato now of Rome,
How I unnerve his Reaſon when I ſpeak,
And make his Rhetorick lacqu't after mine.
That Souldier too, the Cethegus of Genoa;
How I can make him by one ſingle word
Rage or be calme, humble or inſolent;
Theſe are good Tooles to work with, I conſeſs,
But 'tis in hands, that mannage 'em like me,
Not in an Emperors, whoſe honeſt ſoul
Sees not the inſide of his own affairs,
But winds and turns, totters, and then grows ſteddy,
Not as his own, but my deſigns require it.
Michael, my faithful friend, though
Seeming Servant—
Write preſently to thy great Lord and mine,
That with all ſpeed that may be, he advances,
And claps before our Walls: I in the Councel
According to my promiſe carry'd it
For War, and to refuſe the Tribute he requires,
The Weſtern Princes the wiſe Emperor
Relys on, will be long conſulting on't
Before that they conclude of our relief,
And longer e're they ſend it.

sp.speaker: Micha.
sp.l: What excuſe
Shall I my Lord make unto Synan Baſſa,
That you have taken in 4000 men
Under this Juſtiniano; Theſe recruits—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Shall make us far more feeble than we were,
As I will order it; for the Senate,
I'le ſtill poſſeſs with jealouſies and fears
Of Laws ſubverting, and religious change,
That they no aid ſhall to the Emperor give;
Then in due time theſe men ſhall mutiny,
And ſo the Town is his: beſides, theſe Aydes
Were the ſole argument againſt Prince Thomazo,
That we would weather out the growing ſtorm
Till larger ſuccors come from Italy.
Inform the Baſſa this under your Cypher,
My Letters of the reſt ſhall ſtreng then yours;
And bid Lorenzo come
So much for Adrianople, now for Rome.
Lorenzo! my ever true Lorenzo; prithee quickly,
Prepare a truſty Currier for Rome,
To the Cardinal Patron; let your Letters be
To this effect; That I've receiv'd his Bills,
And thank him for 'em; Tell him too
The Warrs decreed in Councel ſpite of Thomazo,
And a Defiance ſent to Mahomet,
Who I believe's on's March: Next, that the Ayds
He or his Holineſs intends to ſend,
Let 'em not come, till joyn'd with th'other Forces
The reſt o'th' Chriſtian Princes may prepare,
They may prove uſeleſs elſe. So far in yours. —
And mine ſhall ſpeak the reſt.
I know their minds—
The Turk muſt take this Town, and then the Pope
Will have no Rival Biſhop in the World.
Let them have their deſign, ſo I can be
G • and Vizier to this growing Monarchy.

stage.hi: Enter Thomazo, Dorello, Irene, Udoxia, attended by Mutantrope.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Was my Ambition, but what's Natural,
To our half-witted Sex. your Highneſs would not
Be troubl'd to purſue, but to avoyd;
But I'le confeſs before Udoxia here,
And your Dorello too, the more you ſpeak
Of Love to me—
The more I muſt deny; nay, I ſhall find
From every new obliging word you utter,
New Arguments to make me obſtinate.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Irene! Can harſh and cruel words like theſe you ſpeak,
Be prompted by your heart, and yet your brow
Calme and ſerene, take no Impreſſions from it.
You deal by me like wanton cruel Judges,
That change a Jeſt with the poor Criminal
Their next breath muſt condemne.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: No Sir, rather
Like a juſt Favourite, who from his Prince
Refuſes to accept ſome mighty Grace,
'Cauſe it may bring his Maſters prudence into queſtion;
I, through your proffer'd friendſhip Sir, can well
Diſcern the Crime of ſtate I ſhould commit
Both 'gainſt your Perſon and this Empire too,
If I ſhould ſuffer you to make me yours.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Wave theſe neglected things Empire & State
They're ſcarce of Kin to me; but if they were,
Power was deſign'd to make its Owner happy;
Not to confine him Slave to Drudge for it.
A Prince, whoſe Title's good, ne're never doubt:
Let him ſtuddy; but his Pow'r is ſo;
If, (as I ne're ſhall wiſh) a Diadem
Should once adorn this head. No act of mine.
Act ſaid I! not the moſt minute Expreſſion
Should flow from one reſtrain'd; No: all ſhould know
What I ſaid ſhould be, ſurely ſhould be ſo.
To one reſolv'd to Reign on Terms like theſe,
The Empires ſafe, let him do what he pleaſe;
So Madam I deſire you would not mix
Affairs of State with my free Love.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Sir, yo're ſo great and gen'rous, you teach me
To be ſo too; therefore I'le plainly tell you
I cannot Marry you, for I already am engag'd.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Madam.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Udoxia, Say no more, it muſt be ſo!
You hear her own it.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: What is that to me?
Tho I confeſs I'm very much amaz'd
To hear her own Paſſion I ne're dream't of.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Aſſoon I ſhould believe Thomazo had
A ſecret, hee'd not let Dorello know
As that Irene has one you not partake.
But Madam; let me dye in your neglects,
Regarded leſs than your weak tatling Woman,
To whom I dare be ſworn you've told all this.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: Go falſe Dorello! go falſe wicked Lord;
I now perceive the end of all your Vows;
It was to mix your paſſion with the Princes,
Not in eſteem of me, but to ſerve him;
But I'm glad this Secret was not Mine to tell you!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Udoxia! you do well.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: No more my Lord,
This is an office for your Serving-man.—

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: My Love, like Mutantrope, your Highneſs Boy,
Does now and then make ſigns, but cannot ſpeak;
This diſſerence only is, my Love can hear,
Though dumb, like him it muſt for ever be.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Let it make ſigns that are as plain as his:
'Tis all I'le ask; I would but know his Name,
Whoſe mighty merit has obtain'd your Love:
Come Mutantrope, teach a Dumb God thy Art—
Ah Boy that this was truth!

stage.hi: Thom. Signes. Mutan. anſwers in ſignes, all liſt,

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: What is't he ſays?

sp.speaker: Thoma.
sp.l: I ſhall but mock my ſelf in telling you:
But yet I will—He ſays that you Love me—

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Fy Sir! you make me bluſh. I know he did not.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: He ſaid it on my life, and ſwore it by ſignes.
I'le ask him, Madam, how he comes to know it!

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Know it! good Dorello, ſay not ſo,
I know my Duty better—if you pleaſe
Ask him, why he thinks ſo—
But pray my Lord, tell Truth; what were his

stage.hi: Dor. makes ſignes; he anſwers them: Thom. whiſpers Iren.

sp.l: Signes?

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: He ſays by This, he's ſure you love his Maſter;
Then, when he brings you Letters, you firſt Kiſs them,
Then thruſt 'em in your Boſom; then reading them,
You Kiſs at every word; beſides, he ſays
You make ſo much of him when he brings Letters,
That he is well aſſur'd you Love the Sender.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Do I not tell you, Madam, juſt the ſame?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Come, he's a Wagg; ſend him no more to me,
He invents all this to pleaſe you!

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The Emperor Sir, has Din'd!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What! will he not be at the Mask, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I ſcarce believe he will; He & the General
Are gone to view theo Wrks—your Highneſs pardon!
Daughter, a word with you—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Udoxia!
Is it not ſad to be ſupplanted thus?—
There, where I thought I'd tane a little root,
Hope in my love, like early bloſſom'd fruit
By one late froſt is nipt.—

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: Sir, I believe it is a blaſting ſeaſon
Of love and friendſhip; both this noiſe of war
Like bitter, black, and rugged North-Eaſt winds,
Drives back the merry Spring of all delights.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, you may truſt Udoxia, none knows better.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: Yes, by Experience, you much more Dorello!—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Is my Friends Fate and mine ſo mixt together,
That I being wretched, he muſt needs be ſo:
I thought to ſigh my griefs to happy Lovers,
That free from their own Cares, might pitty me!

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: I hope your Highneſs needs it not, ſince now.
Dorello has left ſiſting me for Secrets
To quarrel with me.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I underſtand not this.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: He will explain it when next he laughs at me.
Irene is going Sir; 'tis time to dreſs.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: The Emperor has given his final Anſwer
To th' Turkiſh Chiaws—all Tribute is deny'd:
So I believe we muſt expect a War:
And that brought home to us; but 'cis no matter;
Our Walls are ſtrong, our People numerous,
Rich too, beyond Saciety; ſo that Souldiers
Will find their Pay, and they ſtill follow that:
Beſides, our Weſtern Aydes, the Cardinal
Does undertake ſhall ſpeedily be here.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: From whence? My Lord, the Pope, for all his Poſts,
I'm ſure does wiſh our Ruine! His help will come
When he has reconcil'd England and France,
So well to joyn their Armes to ſuccour us,
That will be never; Spain is ſtill ſtrugling
Againſt the Moores; and Germany
Is buſi'd with Religious Mutineers:
Whence muſt come Succour then, except from Heaven,
And our own Courages; which could we joyn
Might do the work: but I do fear that too.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Firſt humbly craving of your Highneſs, pardon
For arguing 'gainſt your Sence; I will remember
The Sultan, as the Chancellor aſſures us,
For all his braggs cannot be here theſe five Moneths:
Then, the Pope has 30 Galleys ready
With 15000nd. men: Theſe Succours will
Within Six weeks be here; or there's no Faith
Left amongſt Chriſtians; for the Cardinal ſwears it.
Then Sir, the States of Genoa and Venice
Will ſend us 40. more; 'Tis their own buſineſs:
Theſe helps are certain Sir—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ay; when they're here!—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Sir, you are all compos'd of Unbelief;
The Councel doubts, the Emperor fears it in you,
And I in humble Duty tell you this.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I know your hearty love does prompt theſe words;
And I am not angry at them; but my Lord,
The Court or Counſels doubts, nor Emperors fears,
Shant make me ſilent, when I ſee my Prince betray'd,
My Prince and Brother too; could I do that
With Juſtice, then they might ſay I was guilty
Of thoſe Ambitious projects that they dream of;
But the falſe Chancellor with all his tricks,
His little purblind tricks of cokeſing parties,
Shall ne're gain me to be a property
For him to ſtalk withal—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I hope your Holineſs
Will eaſily believe I had no deſign
To put you into paſſion; but my Lord,
'I is time to change the ſubject—Sir, the Court
Does come in Maſquerade tho'tis by day-light,
To avoyd the Danger that ſome fewds may bring.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then 'tis not a ſet Maſque.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: No, nothing but a Dance, or ſo
Mixt with all freedom, for the Court Spectators
To mend the Sports themſelves by their own Dancing.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Dorello come! Let you and I go dreſs—

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Your Highneſs humble Creature.

stage.hi: Enter a Servant, Andrea and Lionello.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Surely the General will come ſee theſe Sports.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.l: No doubt on't, let's ſtay for him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Noble Captains!
All perſons will be here incognito,
It is the orders of the Entertainment,
And you muſt needs comply, or go away.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Muſt! to a Souldier; Sawſy Groom, we won't;
Let the Court-Butter-ſlies come how they will,
We are reſolv'd to ſhew our faces here.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My Lord Chamberlain will be angry Sir: Theſe
Are his Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: We care not whoſe they be, nor for his anger;
Our Swords will find an univerſal freedom
In ſpight of your Court-tricks—then hold your prating—

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Well Gallants, mark the end on't.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Theſe are Women Lionello ſure—

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.l: Ladys, The number's equal, and the field cleer,
Why ſhould we not engage?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ha! Dumb! theſe ſure are moving Statues.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: But of Pigmalion's making, fit for Man.
I'le feel if this be warm; how! Coy, Lady!
Not a ſoſt touch go down; 'tis pitty Faith
I han't you ſingly here; wee'd ſure feel out
A better underſtanding e're we parted.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: How got theſe rude men in I wonder Cozen?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Ne'r mind them Madam, the Officers will come
And ſend 'em hence anon.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No Demi-treble, there's none ſo bold that dares it:
Therefore good Queen o'th' Diamonds, let me try
How the Cherries of your lips taſt.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Inſolent Baffoon! ſtand off.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: How's this? So nimble with your upper tire,
I'le try what bore your neather Quarters carry.
Come, at 'em Lionella.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Ruffians! what rudeneſs is this? Know you this place?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What an old Fool it is to ask that queſtion.
Old men are ſilly things: but Lionello,
That ſhall not ſpoile our ſport.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Sure Gallants, theſe
Are no becoming actions in a Court—
Such places ſhould be Sacred.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ay ſo are Churches, yet ſome are ſo wicked as to appoint
Bawdy Meetings there—
Sacred—a pretty word! Alas, my Lord,
Your Dancing-days are done; all places now
Are Sacred where you come, except for ſpitting.

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.l: Sure this old Lord Andrea has been right
When he was young; he now does ſo contrive
To bring young things a clicketting together.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Since you are Strangers, I forgive your rudeneſs;
But pray be gone and learn ſome better manners
Againſt next time you come; or you will find
This place no Court of Guard—

sp.speaker: Lionel.
sp.l: Oh Heaven's Andrea!
How the old Creature raves: Prithee Good man,
Conſider Turks are coming. Turks d'you hear!—
What place will then be Sacred, if we don't
By our undaunted Courage keep them ſo!
In fine, do you ſee my Lord, we know this place
To be our Garriſon, where wee'l be free,
Nay too, without the Laws of Maſquerade—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ay Maſquerade is Sacred too; I'le warrant you
Though t' be intended to help folks to do—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What?—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: It has but an odd name, and fitter 'tis
To practice, than to ſpeak it. Stand but ſtill
Wee'l make your old Chops water preſently.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Villains forbear! Ho Azo! Ho Aroſto!

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Keep your old Chops together, I'le
Cut your Throat elſe.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What Inſolence is this? Villains, Slaves!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: This is ſome real Devil ſure, he fights ſo.
sp.stage: [He throws down one, and diſarms the other.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: That needs not be; for you Ladies, you are ſafe.
What are you, dare do this?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: We are Souldiers, like your Highneſs: Italian Officers:
We were on ſlight diſcoveries pickeering a little.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your General ſhall know this; There, ſecure them.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: To th'Porters Lodge with them—ha! Is't you.
What made you out ſo ſoon?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: T'avoid being known! for who could think ſuch Ruffians
Could have got in! I hope your Highneſs has not receiv'd a hurt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No new one: But I'le go
Out for a little time, and ſhiſt my ſhape, and then return;
I elſe may ſpode the Mirth, by being known.

stage.hi: Enter Caliſta; they go to Mask: She unmasks.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: 'Tis our beſt way to do ſo too Udoxia.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis too late Ladies, I know you both;
But I will be ſo juſt, you ſhall know me.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Caliſta! 'Tis a pretty Veſt that you have on.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: But I do like your dreſs much better Madam—

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: 'Tis not the Cloaths, but Friendſhip prompts this liking;
As change, and you will ſee.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Withal my heart.—

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I readily conſent.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: Come then retire,
You'l ſee 'tis not the Cloaths you both admire.
sp.stage: [Muſick plays; Enter ſeveral perſons as to Maſquerade; amongſt them Thomazo, Dorello, Irene, Udoxia, and Caliſta.

stage.hi: After the Song, a Dance led by Ambition, Repreſented by a Monſter with many Bodies, and but one Head, with a Crown upon it, follow'd by War, Famine, Murder, and Death: The Dance brought up by Fame, repreſented by one Body, and ſeveral Heads and Hands, each having a Trumpet in it. Towards the end of the Dance Thomazo removes towards Caliſta, ſuppoſing her to be Irene by her Habit.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This is Irene; I know her by her Dreſs:
Love, Madam, like to yours, is a worſe Monſter
Than black Ambition is deſcrib'd to be;
For Fame attending him does always ſound
Such loud Alarmes to the drowzy World,
That men to Armes can fly for their defence;
But againſt ſilent Love there is no guard.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Love tells me 'tis the Prince Thomazo's voyce!
But why all this to me? I cannot tell,
Except my heart has taught my eyes to ſpeak
And ſay that bleeds for him.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: My Mutantrope
Has by his ſignes, I fear, done me ſome hurt:
But Madam, be not too ſeverely angry;
He ne're ſhall take that liberty again.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: 'Tis he, the naming of his Mutantrope confirms it.
Now mighty Love aſſiſt me, and I'le be
Thy Votereſſe for ever.
Noble Prince!
Your Highneſs Love has choſen too low an object,
If I be it, as I ſhall ever doubt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Madam, ſay not ſo!—

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Why ſhould Thomazo ſingle thus Caliſta.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: You made me Madam, more than happy now.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: What's this? Curſt be my Ears for hearing it,
And Curſt be all men for Thomazo's ſake!
Is he ſo amorous that Caliſta can
Poſſeſs a place in that falſe heart of his;
Caliſta, whom he always ſeem'd to loath
For being Daughter to the Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Madam! I'le keep my word; no trick of State
Shall bar my happineſs: At break of Day,
In St. Sophia's Church I'le meet you, Madam,
Juſt by our Ladies Altar: Bring Udoxia,
I'le bring Dorello, they will be enow
To witneſs we are Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: But falſe man!
You ſhall have more, for I'le be there my ſelf
To throw thy broken Vows 'mongſt thoſe you make:
Thoſe ſhall give Plagues to all your Nuptial hours,
And change the Bleſſings of the Prieſts to Curſes.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Let not your Father know the leaſt of this,
That Notice may not be taken of our Whiſpers.
I'le lead you out to Dance.

sp.speaker: Udox.
sp.l: Be not too raſh, conſider 'tis your ſelf
Did give him cauſe for this; you own'd you Lov'd,
And ſaid with all, you ne're could Marry him.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: In ſuch an Aire, and ſuch a Tone I ſpoke it;
It could not mean him ill.
But ſee my Father.—

stage.hi: Enter Theophilus, Emperor, Juſtiniano, Andrea, Lionello, Mutantrope, Guards.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: The Emperor is preſent, and commands
That all avoyd the Room, who're in Diſguiſe,
Except the Prince Thomazo.—Pray withdraw.

sp.speaker: Emper.
sp.l: Brother, 'tis ſtrange you bear no more reſpect
To our Commands, nor to the General,
But have Impriſon'd theſe two Officers
Without his Privity.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I know your Majeſty did ne're intend
To exempt them from common Juſtice,
And make them Lawleſs. Their Inſolence—

sp.speaker: Juſtian.
sp.l: Inſolence! How mean you by that word?
I'd have your Highneſs eat it up again,
And call't neglect.—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How! eat my words my Lord?
The Sacred preſence of this dread Majeſty
Reſtraines me, or by Heav'n—

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: What would you elſe?
Nay, what durſt you do my Lord? my Honour
Full fledg'd can mount above your weak obſervance,
Though you're oth'Eagles Brood.—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How's this? My Lord, do you our Brother know?
And where you ſpeak this to him?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Yes Sir! or—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Or what? Let not your Pride profane this—

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Profane a—

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Out of our preſence.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Ay, and your Empire to.
I'le beat my Drums but for an exerciſe,
And ſport my men out of your large Dominions—

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Seize on the Traytor!—So, convey him hence
To the Caſtle, Priſoner. I'le ne're indure this.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Send all my men to Priſon too, elſe in vain
You hope to keep me here.—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your Majeſty
May now perceive the Inſolence of Strangers,
When once they know you need them: But I am
Too blame to urge this now—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No, not at all;
By this one hours diſcourſe I have had with him,
I find his Pride to be beyond enduring;
He boaſts our Safety muſt proceed from him,
And quotes the Chancellor for ſaying this;
I do begin to doubt the Arts of him too.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, he's a Traytor, or I'm not a man.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Majeſty muſt pardon this Intruſion,
Your Highneſs too; my haſty Zeal requires it;
Letters juſt now arriv'd bring certain word
The Sultan's on his March, and will this Night
Be lodg'd before our Walls.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How's this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: By this Surprizal we are loſt for ever.
Ah gracious Heav'n, take back this burden, life,
Before I ſee the Miſeries are coming.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This ill agrees my Lord with your laſt news
Of five moneths hence, they cou'd not come before;
But 'tis what I expected—This ſuddain danger
Muſt prompt your Majeſty with double Vigour.
To make ſharp oppoſition—Sir, arreſt
All Ships are in the Harbour, ſieze their ſtores
Of Guns and Ammunition—with the Guards,
And ſome oth' Genoway Foot: I'le out and meet 'em—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No! I am reſolv'd
To Head our firſt attempt with my own perſon.
The Turks ſhall find 'tis not our want of Courage,
But factions in our State that makes them be
Succeſsful ſtill in all their Wars againſt us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Good Sir be pleas'd to truſt me with this Sally:
Your preſence is moſt needful in the Town;
At ſuch a time as this you'l find the people
Prompted by fear too apt for all ſedition;
May be the Souldiers too may take advantage
Of the firſt uprore which this news will bring,
And fall to doing miſchief; beſides great Sir,
You'l find new Orders every minute needful,
Which none but your Authority can give.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Your reaſons ſhall perſwade me, go Thomazo,
And may Heav'n Crown thy Sword with Victory.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Good Sir be ſtrong
To your Imperial ſelf, that's all I'le ſay;
If ſo, I make no doubt by th'help of Heav'n
To drive this Sultan back with as much ſhame.
As once his Father found when he beſieg'd us.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: The Prince does ſhew a great and generous Soul,
And will no doubt perform all that he ſpeaks;
But give me leave to think he has his ends
In all he does or ſays—Sir, this advice
Of ſeizing all the Ships, the Senate ſitting
With wonted freedom, I muſt boldly ſay
Shews he would put you on ungrateful things,
Whilſt he purſues the popular himſelf.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: My Lord, your Circumſpection wears a Cloud
I cannot well ſee through; and I muſt tell you
Your ſalſe Intelligence and cloſe intriguing
Give me ſome hints for doubts; but let your actions
Wear a more candid out-ſide, 'tis not elſe
Your Intereſt in the Senate ſhall protect you.
No Sir! it ſhall not! but no reply my Lord:
As for my Brother, I am ſure he loves me;
I've found he has, and cannot now ſuſpect him.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Do not Sir; but yet I muſt attempt
T'unlooſe one charme h'has plac'd upon your Soul.
That's Sir, about the General—'Tis not a time
To ſtand on ſlight punctilio's with ſuch men
As underſtand them not: This his reſtraint
May chance endanger all; grant Sir, his freedom.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: I cannot do't, and Majeſty be ſafe:
His Inſolence both to the Prince and me
Was more then Brutal—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: But your Majeſty
Should well conſider leading Circumſtances
That did provoke him to't: The Prince you know
Had 'gainſt conditions of his Entertainment
Impriſon'd two of's Captains—

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Speak no more on't;
"I'le not releaſe him till my Brother pleaſe;
"Contempt of Pow'r is a State's worſt Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: THeſe doubts of theirs concerning ſuch wild things,
That Soveraign Pow'r may do, amaze me;
Becauſe 'tis poſſible we may do harm,
Will they conclude we certainly do it?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Majeſty
Has had no cauſe to doubt their ſteddy Loves
To your Imperial Intereſt and Perſon.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: 'Tis true, my Lord, nor can my memory
Prompt me with want of care of them or theirs:
None of my Predeceſſors ever were
More careful of Propriety than I;
Therefore I cannot chuſe but take unkindly
Motions, like theſe, juſt on the Neck of War.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Our Scouts are beaten in; the Turks Van-guard
Are eaſily diſcern'd from off the Steeples,
Which does all the Streets produce the Crys
Of Women, Children, and the heartleſs Crowd
That nothing but Confuſion fills the Town.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: It can't be help't; my Lord, we muſt endure it.
Theſe Noiſes fill the Streets of every place,
When they are firſt beſieg'd; a day or two
Will quiet all their minds.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: I hope it will; but, my Lord Chancellour,
The ſhort five moneths, ſince morning, makes me doubt
I have unknown unto my ſelf been ſleeping;
Or elſe that your Intelligence deceives you:
Or if not that, then you deceive us all.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Methinks, my Lord, the liberty you take,
Doth ſcarce become this Preſence.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Why, my Lord,
I'm ſure his Majeſty will pardon me,
Since 'tis my plain and honeſt heart that ſpeaks;
And I muſt own, it was your bold affirming,
That we had full five moneths for preparation,
Which got my Vote for War. But now I fear
The Rumour's true, that you have got a Turk
To manage your Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: How's this?
Your Majeſty, I hope, will do me Juſtice
Againſt this Calumny?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Lord Chamberlain,
What grounds have you for this?

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Truly no more
Than half the Lords o'th' Councels juſt ſuſpition;
Nay, the better half; but they perchance may err,
It is not the firſt time, witneſs the approaching Siege.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: My Lord, you would have done more like a Friend
I' have told me of ſuch Rumours privately.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Good my Lord, is not this Preſence private?
Who's here but's Majeſty, and you, and I;
As I am a Privy Councellour I ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Explain your ſelf; who, and what is't you mean?

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: I mean you have a Secretary call'd Michael.—
Some ſay he's a Turk;
And this Sir is the Man.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: What cauſes this Intruſion?

sp.speaker: Micha.
sp.l: I come in haſte
To give you notice all the Engliſh Ships,
And the Venetian too, are under Sail;
Except they be arreſted preſently,
They will get paſt the Forts.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Is not the Warrant iſſu'd for their ſtay?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: A Broad-Seal-Warrant too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: That Sir they ſlight.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: They might ſlight Death as well.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Sir, they pretend
The Senate ſays it is againſt the Law,
That they ſhould be Arreſted.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Think of that Sir;
If they reſent the deed, 'tis not the ſtores
Of thoſe few Ships can recompence the loſs
Of their affections.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Nor can their beſt Zeal
Find ſuch another timely ſuccour near
To draw to our ſupply.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Do as you pleaſe,
But I dare pawn my life that they'l be troubl'd?

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: At their departure moſt, I'le warrant you;
At nothing elſe, my Head on't.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: But what then?
Shall I neglect my duty to the whole
For private mens reſentments? Come, my Lord,
I'le ſee it done my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Michael! how is't?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Gone Sir; beyond Redemption; both the Conſuls
Were at your Houſe but now: There I advis'd them,
With all the haſte that might be, to ſet Sail,
Whatever Orders they ſhou'd ſee to ſtop them.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: 'Tis very well; then you are ſure they're gone?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: My Zeal had never ſeem'd ſo earneſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: That happen'd well though: 'twill clear a late ſuſpition
That you're a Turk.—
But more of that anon—You ſent the Warrant.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Aye Sir; but gave command to him that went
To ſay you ſeal'd it much againſt your will:
Beſides, I ſpread it every where abroad,
That 'twas againſt the Law; ſo none would act by't.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: That is a certain Method to confound things;
And 'tis the way I'le take; for I perceive
I've loſt ſome ground i'th' Emperours affections,
And now muſt keep my Pow'r more by the Vogue
O'th' Senate, than his love; but let's go out,
And view Thomazo's Actions in the Field;
'Tis to his Genius only mine does yield.

stage.hi: Great Shouts and Noiſe of Fighting: Enter Thomazo, Dorello, Officers with Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Theſe Turks are leſs than Women in our hands;
Where e're we ſhew our Faces, ſtill they fly;
If but the reſt o'th' Forces ſally'd out,
This Night would make a perfect end o'th' Siege.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Their great Forlorn is routed totally,
And their Main Body ſtaggar'd, five thouſand more
Would have perſorm'd the work.—In all the Fight
I met but one brave Foe that durſt make Head;
And when my Sword had made him Priſoner,
He prov'd a Genowees.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What did you with him?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Clapt my Sword through him Sir.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: You did do well;
A Renogado Dog is ripe for Hell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: See my Lord, they'r marching on agen—
Will you to Horſe?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: The Hedges make them uſeleſs;
I'le Charge i'th' Head of yonder Stand of Pikes.

stage.hi: Shouts.—Enter Turks drove in by Synan, Muſtapha, and other Baſſa's.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: What wretched fearful Slaves! dare you not die?
Can you forget the Laws of Deſtiny?

sp.speaker: Muſta.
sp.l: Fight; or the Death you'd ſhun, you'l ſooner find;
Our Swords give Death to all who ſeek to fly.

stage.hi: Shouts.—Enter Thomazo, Dorello, and Chriſtians: They ſight a while, the Turks retire ſighting. Thomazo, Dorello, re-enter in haſte.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: To Horſe, to Horſe, the Genoway Body ſhrinks. Let's
Preſently relieve them.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Theſe Chriſtians fight, as if the General Cauſe
Did wield each Sword.—Curſe on our wretched Slaves,—
How faſt they Rout!—Lead on the Grand Reſerve
To ſuccour the Main Body.—Now by my Fathers Soul,
Morat's ſtrong Troop of our beſt Spahi Horſe,
Fly like looſe leafs before the Autumn wind:
We 're betray'd by that Damn'd Chancellour:
Their ſtrength's the Flower of all the Chriſtian World,
They could not fight thus elſe.—Oh mighty Prophet!
Protect our Sultan's Glory.—
Let not a Cheating Gown-man boaſt he had
Great ſums from us for nothing elſe but ſhame.
But yet it will be ſo; our great Reſerve
Under the Grand Vizier does ſtagger too:—
Draw up our Guards, let's ſave or ruine all;
'Tis better much to die than wear the ſhame

Of be •…
〈◊〉 defeated by a handful.

stage.hi: Enter Emperour, Cardinal, Chancellour, Theo. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Cardin.
sp.l: The Prince I ſwear perform'd prodigious things!
They'd be incredible but that we ſaw them.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Accurſed ſight!
The Turkiſh Army's ſure compos'd of Women.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Theophilus, Command that all the Forces
Do preſently draw out; I will my ſelf
Share part o'th' Glory in the Turks Defeat.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Good Sir, conſider
What 'tis you mean to do? Will you expoſe
Your Sacred Perſon 'mongſt the Genoweeſe,
That openly avow their diſcontents?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No, let them ſtay behind; I am ſatisfi'd
That our own Forces are enough without them,
To ſecond this Succeſs, and Rout the Turks.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: But ſay Sir, when you're out with all your ſtrength,
That they ſhould ſeize the Town.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: They dare not ſure.—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: It is but ill to try inraged Strangers;
Beſides the Night comes on.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Good Sir, ſend out, and do not go your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: The Prince I'm confident will take that ill.
'Twill ſeem to doubt his Courage, or his Conduct.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: His Soul's above all Envy I am ſure:
But I'le go try the temper of the Souldiers,
Then either back the Sally, or go meet him.

stage.hi: Enter Irene, Udoxia, Caliſta, meeting the Emperour; they Salute, and part.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: She triumphs in his Love, and makes me Mad.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Conceal your anger Madam, 'tis too clear.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: By Nature I am temperate as Day;
When gentle Weſtern Gales blow in the Spring;
But now I could grow rugged like the North,
And in a Tempeſt of my Fury tear
Thoſe Eyes out that have thus bewitch'd my Prince.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Bear up; my mind perſwades me he is not ſalſe,
Though ſhe invites me for her Bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: But will you go?

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Aye, with deſign to ſerve you,
By putting him in mind of •… Vows to you.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Do not do that; no, let her take his heart;
But yet I know not why: I'le meet you there.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Oh that the Prince would come, I long to ſee him—
I hope he is not hurt.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: What if he be?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: I would not for the world he ſhou'd methinks.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Nay, ſure i'th' world there's many better Princes.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: No, I believe not one, if we conſider
His moſt Heroick Courage, and wiſe Conduct.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Beſides his Faith in Love; pray name that too.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Irene—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Sure ſhe does gueſs at ſomething that has paſt
Between the Prince and me, which ſtirs her Envy.

stage.hi: Enter Emperour, Thom. Cardin. Theop. Dorell. Mutantrope, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This is the Cauſe of our too quick return;
The Genoway Body did betray the Field;
And now do ſeem to threaten Mutiny:
They bring indeed the War within our Walls:
Had I been ſeconded with the like number
Of our own Nation, we had done the work.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: To th' ſpecious reaſons of the Chancellour
I muſt impute the loſs of this Days Triumph;
I did my ſelf intend to ſecond you.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Great Sir, blame not that Counſel did proceed
From Zeal to th' Princes Glory, and your ſafety.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I beg, my Lord, you'd ſpare your daily pains
In ſerving me in theſe unthankful ways.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: 'Tis my misfortune Sir, they always prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Brother, you had theſe Ladies hearty wiſhes
For good ſucceſs and ſafety, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: 'Twas thoſe, next to your Fortune, did preſerve me:
But Lady, may I think I was ſo happy
To have my ſhare in the laſt Pray'rs you made?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I ſhould have loſt my Senſe of Duty elſe;
You are a Mighty Prop o'th' Empire Sir,
And ſo, and no ways elſe I pray'd for you.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How's this?—She does diſſemble to extremity.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: He caſts not the leaſt glance on me!—'tis well,
He ſtrives to keep things ſecret.
Noiſe without. One and all, one and all, &c.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: The Genowees are in Mutiny,
And ſwear they'l have their General ſet free,
Or elſe they'l fire the Town.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I adviſe to hang their General,
That will ſoon quiet them; but if it don't,
Then let the other Souldiers fall upon 'em,
And knock 'em all o'th' heads;—if they hold on
As they've begun, they'l do but little ſervice:
Thoſe Thouſand I had with me firſt did rout
With all the men I had.—Sir, there's no way
But ſudden Execution, or good words;
Hanging or granting ſtill, quells Mutinies.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Well, draw up the Court-guards about the Palace,
Then act as you ſee cauſe.

stage.hi: Ex. all but Thom. Dor. and Mutantrope.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I find the Chancellour by little Arts
Prevented our Relief with greater Succours:
But I perceive my Brother ſo ſuſpects him,
He'l ſcarce prevail again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I wiſh he don't;
But you have heard the Shipping all are ſail'd?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Aye, there's another Trick of his contriving;
I'd almoſt pawn my life.—But we muſt play
The Cards we ſtill have leſt, or loſe the Game.
But all diſcourſe of State and War apart,
Let's talk of Love a little now Dorello;
In what condition's yours and fair Ʋdoxia's?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Juſt as your Highneſs left it, full as bad
As yours with fair Irene.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If it be no worſe,
Tis as you'd wiſh't I'm ſure; for to be ſhort,
To morrow Morn before the Sun doth riſe,
I meet Irene in S. Sophta's Church,
Where you are to be witneſs of our Marriage.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Can this be ſo?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ʋdoxia will confirm it,—for ſhe is to be there.
Come let's away,
sp.stage: A Noiſe agen, One and All.
sp.l: And quell theſe Mutiniers. They fright the Town.

stage.hi: Enter Juſtiniano, Andrea Lionella, and Souldiers.—Shouting.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: I thank you Fellow-Souldiers for your love,
I'd rather have my Liberty by you,
Than by their ſlighted favour.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: See the Prince!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What means this Tumult? Ha! Juſtiniano Head it!
VVhat are your Demands?

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Our Pay we'd have.—
sp.stage: [ Thomaz. runs the Sould. through, they all hang their heads.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: There's thine.—Now, what the reſt?
Then worthy General yours.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Revenge for late affronts given me by thee.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Dorello—I Command—that word's not uſual;
But I Command not a man ſtir to help me,
Except oppreſt by Numbers.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: I the ſame.
Then take my Life, for I deſpiſe to beg it.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Or I to take it; no, the Law ſhall do it.
All to your Quarters; I'le procure your Pardons:
If not, fall on, and kill 'em every man.
Convey him back to'th' Caſtle where he was.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: To morrow, ſair Irene, to morrow morn!

sp.speaker: Mut.
sp.l: Aye Sir, I heard him tell Dorello ſo.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: In S. Sophia's Church by break of day,
Near to our Ladies Altar; is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Mutan.
sp.l: Aye, my Lord, ſo the appointment's made.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Well, my good Boy, watch cloſe upon his actions,
And bring me word of every thing thou gain'ſt.

sp.speaker: Mutan.
sp.l: I ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Marry Irene!—no, it muſt not be,—it ſha'nt:
But how ſhall I prevent it? there's it!—To tell
The Emperour, would but betray my ſelf!
For I've no proof to vouch, but this ſame Boy,
Which I preſented him as a choice Mute,
To be a Spy for me on all his actions—
But yet I muſt prevent it, that's decreed—
His two laſt Actions ſhew he is a Prince,
Not of a common Fortune,
To ſhake the Turks whole Army with a handful,
And quell that Mutiny in half a Minute,
In which I plac'd my hopes; were things prodigious,
His Mighty Genius has a ſtrong Attendant
O're all my Fortune.—I muſt remove him—
'Tis no matter how, ſo I can do't.—

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Amongſt Thomazo's Souldiers, there got in
Two Spies from Synan B • ſſa, both with Letters,
I have decipher'd them.—The firſt, it ſeems,
Were writ before the Fight, and only ſpeak
The Numbers that beſiege us, and require
An hourly intercourſe during the Siege:
The ſecond are purſuant to the Sally writ in heat,
And there, my Lord, they are.—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: O Michael! I am loſt to all my hopes;
The Sultan frowns, it ſeems, and doubts my Faith.
He ſays the Sally had lik'd to have prov'd the loſs
Of their whole Army.—What ſhall I do?
This Prince Thomazo does,
Like ſome tall Cedar, blaſt my Underwood.
I muſt deſtroy him. Find me out ſome Jew
That ſtudies Phyſick—No, I've another way—
Write Letters to the Baſſa that may ſpeak
What I've done this day towards the Service.
The Chriſtian Ships are ſail'd, and I prevented
More Forces that were going to the Sally,
Beſides the Mutiny Lorenzo ſtir'd
Amongſt his Countrymen—and all things elſe—
O th' doubts I raiſe i'th' Senate—remember all—
But here's a Sacrifice of Peace I'le make,
This is the Picture of the fair Irene;
I got it from my Daughter; ſend it him,
And tell him, that the Original ſhall be
Lodg'd in his Maſters Arms to morrow night.
Prepare a ſcore of Ruffians with a Barge
To carry off the Prize; it ſhall go hard,
But I'le ſend off the Prince Thomazo too:
You know the way of holding Correſpondence;
I'le ſay no more of that—go, haſte your Letters,
And ſend Lorenzo hither.
I'le go meet
In ſome diſguize the diſcontented Captains.
Lorenzo! I am reſolv'd to laugh to night,
And ſpend ſome hours with frolick Woman-kind.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: My Lord, you know your old houſe, Mother Somelies,
You know ſhe always fits you with freſh Girls.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Aye, there we'll be; but then for Company,
Get your two Friends, the Captains, if you can,
I mean thoſe two that were made Priſoners.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I'm confident with joy they'l meet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I would be thought ſome wild looſe Friend of yours
That mean to treat.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I underſtand your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Some two hours hence. Till then I will to Court.

stage.hi: Enter Emperour, Thomazo, Cardinal, Dorel. Theophilus, Mutant. Irene, Udoxia, Caliſta, Attendants, as at Court.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Pray Madam, how ſeems Time to move to you,
To me it does appear extreamly ſlow.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: It may be ſo, my Lord, but unto me
He keeps his uſual pace.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Madam,
Your coldneſs now ſurprizes me as much
As did the Larum of your Love to day.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Good, my Lord, you'l make Caliſta jealous.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: You are too cautious, Madam.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: She's not ſo.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: My Lord, Good-night,
I am a bad Diſſembler of Paſſion,
I find it will break out; therefore I'le go
And waſte this Night in Tears.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Why ſo Irene?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: My Lord, no more, I ſtill muſt wiſh you well.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Remember ſix a Clock.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I ſhall have cauſe.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I ſhall bring Company will ſpoil the Sport;—
Your Highneſſes Boy I ſee waits very cloſe:
I never ſee him from you.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No, 'tis a pretty Spaniel,
He's always diligent to Fetch and Carry.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I'm glad I did preſent him to your Hig! ne's,
Since he's ſo acceptable.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: All Favours
That I receive from you muſt needs be ſo.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: My Lord, I am ſorry my Duty to my Maſter,
Should make me doubt my Service unto you,
As your words hint.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No Argument i'th' Preſence;
I think you for my Boy, that's all my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: It cannot be, my Lord, the Prince and You
Are both (I'le ſay no more) but you're both men;
And what h' has promis'd is not to Irene,
But to Caliſta there.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You do amaze me:
This wild diſcourſe has no Connexion in it.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: A great deal more than has your wilder Action.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: I'le call the Prince to hear you.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Ʋdoxia—

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Caliſta calls, I cannot ſtay my Lord.—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sallies will ſpend our men to little purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: 'Twill rather make us Souldiers; every Sally
Made with freſh men will ſoon experience.
Had all men Courages but like your Highneſs,
Experience then, 'tis true, was only needful;
But moſt by Nature are unfit for War.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: My Lord, you are miſtaken; I affirm,
There's not a man of able Bulk and Strength,
But may be brought to fight proportionably,
At leaſt in Crowds they may.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Admit it ſo:
But will the Emperour, or Senates Prudence,
Suffer your Highneſs ſtill t'expoſe your Perſon
To hourly danger; when the Empires Hopes,
Is next his Majeſty, all plac'd in you.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Aye, now you've touch't the String that hits my Fancy;
Your Perſonal ſafety Brother; Surely that
Ought to be all our care, and ſhall be mine;
I am confident no Sally can be ſafe
Without you Head it, nor you in any one;
Therefore we will relye on future Succours.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thoſe from his Holineſs will ſoon be here,
Beſides the Rhodian and Venetian Forces,
I'm confident will not be long behind.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Theſe are meer Dreams of Safety.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Wait a little;
We have an open Port to Aſia-ward,
And cannot want Proviſions. Good-night Brother.

stage.hi: Ex. all but Thom. Dor. Mut.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: You ſee Dorello, this cunning Gown-man
Is grown ſo tender of my Perſons ſafety,
That to keep me well, the Turk muſt not be Beat.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I blame him not, now you're to Marry his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I Marry her!—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So Ʋdoxia tells me,
And that to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: 'Tis ſhort warning;
But who has made the Match?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I know not that;
But ſhe ſays this you promis'd at the Mask.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Piſh! ſhe miſtakes, it was the Fair Irene
I only ſpoke to there.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How's this? there's ſome miſtake: Was it the Lady
That you Danc'd with you made the Promiſe to?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Aye, what of that!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then Sir it was Caliſta.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: It is impoſſible, her Dreſs was that
Irene had on, when the Souldiers ruffl'd her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Sir, that may be, but yet it was Caliſta,
I ſaw her after when her Mask was off,
And had a Complement from her.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: But why ſhould ſhe accept my firſt Addreſs?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That her Ambition taught! But will you meet?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I wou'd meet Death much ſooner.—You ſhall go
And undeceive her, if it is She that comes;
But I'le be near, in hopes 'twill prove Irene.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thoſe hopes will quickly vaniſh in your Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This Chancellour, like ſome unlucky Star,
Does interpoſe his Direful Influence
Through all my Happineſs in Love or Honour.
How ſtrangely
Wiſe Heav'n with unſeen Links makes Chains of Fate,
This Hawks good Fortune that's unfortunate.

stage.hi: Enter Chanc. Loren. Andr. Lion. with 4 Wenches, and Fiddles.

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.l: You are the Maddeſt Man I ever met with,

l.hi: Now Fruition has empti'd our Bottles of Love,
Let the Bottles of Wine fly about;
The heat of that Fire,
Shall inflame our deſire,
And Phlegmatick Dulneſs remove.
A Health to the beſt,
A Pox o'th' reſt,
And hey for the t'ther brisk Bout.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Come, Faith Madam, once again.

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.l: Pray Sir ſtay, I am not i'th' humour.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: See, ſee, here's Gold; will this exalt thy humour?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: See there! You Scurvy Queans, did you fear Sconces?

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.l: I hope, my Dear, you'l give me ſome Silk Stockins.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Aye, and rich Garters too; there's twenty Pieces,
Rig thy whole Veſſel! what, haſt found thy humour?

sp.speaker: 1 Wench.
sp.l: Aye, my Dear, you are ſuch another man.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Signior Lorenzo! your Friend's a Man of Mettle.
What does he give all that?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Alas, that's nothing.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.l: My Dear, will you give me ſome?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Aye, there—there's 20 Pieces for thee.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: But you Inhance the Price moſt damnably,
I've had a better Whore for half a Crown.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.l: Whore! you foul-mouth'd Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Aye Whore, what came we for but Whore?

sp.speaker: 3 Wench.
sp.l: But, my Dear.
sp.stage: The other two Wenches Dun the Captains round the Stage.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.l: My Dear, why wou'd you bring ſuch Shabby Fellows
With you?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: They're honeſt Gentlemen, tho' they want Money.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.l: Honeſt, faugh! A poor Rogue can't be honeſt;
But you are the Goodeſt Man. Prithee, my Dear,
Lend me but 10 l. more, and you will make me.—

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Ten pound, what's that! here 'tis for one bare Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Hold Signior, for half that I've compounded;
I want it but to pay, pray lend it me.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: And me the reſt; I ſhan't have time to drink elſe.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I beg your Pardon, I muſt not ſtarve my Love.

sp.speaker: 3 Wench.
sp.l: Your Love, 'tis a fine one, ſhe ply'd i'th' Town
Seven years before I knew it.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: That's no matter;
She has the more experience. I am conſtant.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.l: So I will be my Dear, for all their Malice.

sp.speaker: 3 Wench.
sp.l: I will not looſe my time thus.

sp.speaker: 4 Wench.
sp.l: Faith, nor I; I could 'een cry my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Now we have time to drink to thee Andrea;
A Pox on High-priz'd Whoring.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: What's here, two Turtles pining without Mates!

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Their Girls went crying ripe for what ours got.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: That muſt not be Ladies; go ſetch 'em in,
I'le ſee them paid, but bring no Tears amongſt us;
No weeping Cupids here, we're for the Boys
That Caper and ſhew Tricks in Ladies Eyes.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: 'Fore Heav'n, the merri'ſt Greek I ever met with;
Is he a Servant o'th' Chancellours?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Faith you are Princes by your Places.
Here's your Lords Health for your ſakes; he's a Maſter
The beſt i'th' Empire, all men ſay that.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Pox o'Great Men, and great things; they both devour
All that one gives without the leaſt delight;
I'm for the Souldiers Health.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Then we're your Men:
We two to night did pay the Turks away.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Each kill'd his Baſſa; though Thomazo Huffs,
As if he had done all: but time will come.
I'le ſay no more,—our General muſt not lye thus.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, by my Sword,—I'le fire the City rather—
But let that paſs, I'le ſing a Song I made
Since we return'd from killing the Baſſa's.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Rogues! that were both in Priſon. But the bette • ,—
A Huffing Coward always proves a Villain.
I'le taſte them by and by.—

l.hi: They come, they come;
Hark, do you hear that Drum?
It is an Alarum to War;
To Love it does Beat,
A Fatal Retreat:
See, ſee, where our Enemies are,
A Noiſe, a Noiſe,
Of Shouts and Dreadful Crys
Has frighted our Scouts, they come in:
Then farewel delight,
Till after the Fight,
We'll Rout them, and at it agen.
They Fly, they Fly,
Hark how they Quarter cry;
Their Valour lies now in their ſpeed:
Their Baſſa's in vain
Would Rally again,
But a Turk delights not to Bleed.
Bring Wine, bring Wine,
What do you ſtill repine?
To truſt a brave Souldier for drink;
The Enemy's run,
Then Souldier be gone,
He'l never return you do think.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: The Wit and Courage of theſe Gentlemen
Deſerves the World Lorenzo ſhould be theirs.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ah Sir! had we our Pay, we'd be contented:
The Emperour owes us near ſix Weeks Pay.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: You ne're ſhall ſigh for that; I'le ſend it you.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: You ſhall have Impreſt Bills that will ſecure you.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: That needs not, one flight favour you may do
Pays me, and trebles that unto your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ask any thing i'th' compaſs of our Swords.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: 'Tis to prevent a Wedding two wou'd ſteal
In S. Sophia's Church by break of day:
A quiet time, you know; if you will ſeize them,
And carry them to the place I ſhall appoint,
Lorenzo will ſee you paid a 1000 Duckets.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: You'l take my word for this, will you not Signior?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Aye, wer't ten times as much—but we muſt have
Some of our Men to help us, muſt we not?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Aye, that you muſt.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I have a Faithful Servant, I'le ſend for him,
And he ſhall pick ſome Men fit for the Work.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: We'll not to Bed to night.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, no Sleep
Till the good work be done. But more Inſtructions.—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: We ſhall have time for that. But where's theſe Women!
I cannot live an hour without a Woman;
Oh they're the uſeful'ſt Creatures:—
Come, let's go ſearch, we muſt mix Love with Wine▪
A Wiſe Man thus ſtill Revels with deſign.

sp.speaker: Mutan.
sp.l: MY Lord is not come; What ſhall I do?
Theſe are Caliſta's Lodgings: Oh that I could
But meet her—I'd venture being known
To be no Mute to her, rather than ſhe
Should be deluded thus. I ſee her coming;
But there's Ʋdoxia too—I muſt not ſpeak
Except I get her ſingle.

stage.hi: Enter Caliſta and Udoxia; the Boy makes Signs to get Caliſta alone.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: How think you now Ʋdoxia?

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: I'm convinc'd;
His Boy confirms your words. Ah poor Irene!

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: See but what Tricks he plays to get me with him.
Come Ʋdoxia—nay, ſhe muſt go with me.

sp.speaker: Mutan.
sp.l: There is no ſeparating them. Where ſhould her
Father be? But I muſt follow.—

stage.hi: Enter Andrea, Lionello, Lorenzo, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: This is the place they meet at: Seize all that come,
The Barge lies ready for you. I'le retire.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Down all upon your Knees; devoutly Rogues,
To Pray'rs, to Pray'rs!

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: That's no uſual word of Command Captain.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Silence, and to your Beads; Knock 'em apace.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: Ha! ſuch a Crowd of Souldiers: Sure 'tis Devotion
To Rob our Lad •… Altar draws them hither
So early in the Morning. Ha! who's here?

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: The Boy is like his Maſter, ſure run Mad.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: The Boy grows troubleſome: but where's his Maſter?

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: Not far off Ladies; but he'll be much ſurpriz'd
To meet you two I know.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Hiſt, hiſt, 'tis they

stage.hi: They muffle Dorello in his Cloak, and carry him, Mut. and the Ladies out.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: Ha! what's?—

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.l: Hoe there! Sacriledge, Sacriledge,
The Sanctuary's violated.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I am come time enough; I'm confident
The Eaſt Door did juſt open: I'le to Pray'rs
Till they arrive.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I muſt needs ſee how this Affair ſucceeds;
Who's this? Val'd! It is ſome Curtezan,
Whoſe hot Devotion has bin up all Night;
My Pray'rs will ſuit with hers—

stage.hi: Kneels by Irene, ſhe pulls off her Glove to feel for a Book; he riſes.

sp.l: Ha! 'tis the Fair Irene! that hand betrays her,
I know it by the Locket.—Lady, your Saint
Is not ſtirring it—But where are all my Rogues
Drinking their Morning's Draught, I'le be hang'd elſe,
Though they've bin up all Night; my Secretary
Does uſe to play me thoſe Tricks.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.l: Here has bin ſad Diſorders in the Church,
A Gentleman, two Women, and a Boy,

〈◊〉
•… ook away by force, and clapt on Board:
A Barge lay at the Key; I ran and call'd,
But all in vain, for none did dare to ſtop them;
Their Genowees's did it.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Reverend Sir,
What ſort of Perſons were thoſe carri'd hence?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: 'Tis She.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.l: Perſons of Quality I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: They are my Dogs have lit' upon wrong Game—
I'le place them in Retrieve—

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n they are not
Some Villains that have ſeiz'd on Prince Thomazo,
I cannot with his Falſhood that hard Fate.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: My Patience is quite loſt by lingring doubt.
What Lady's this?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Ha! here's the Prince Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: May I preſume to ask a Queſtion Lady?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: What Queſtion Sir?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Know you the Fair Irene?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Yes; and Caliſta too; but good Sir, peace.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your words make me half think you know my bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I know 'em both too well.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis Irene!

stage.hi: Enter Chancellour, Andr. Lionel. Souldiers: They ſeize Irene, and convey her out, whilſt the Captain engage Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: There's the Woman.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Help me Thomazo! help!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Villains unhand her, ſhe is worth your lives.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And Livelihoods too boot: Therefore no paſſing.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I'le give you double Hire, and Pardon too.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Ha! Prince Thomazo, I'le keep my double diſtance.

stage.hi: Enter Prieſts and ſeize on Thom. Captains run away.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.l: Sacriledge, Sacriledge! Murder, Murder!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Unhand me Fools—your Sanctuary's broke;
The Fair Irene is forc'd away by Villains.

sp.speaker: 1 Prieſt.
sp.l: We beg your Highneſs Pardon.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Spare your Complements, and make purſuit;
The Fair Irene is loſt elſe.

stage.hi: Enter Chancellour, Irene, Loren. Captains Souldiers: The Chanc. diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: To ſhew you whom you ſerv'd; behold, 'tis me:
Diſpair not of full Recompence—Lorenzo,
Go Treat the Noble Captains like themſelves,
And give the Souldiers Belly-fulls of Wine.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: We humbly thank your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Villains! tell me!
How did you leave the Prince?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Truly, Madam,
We left him in the hands of Ghoſtly Fathers.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Oh Heav'ns! the Prince in danger.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Madam, don't
Afflict your ſelf, for you will find a Prince
Of far more Pow'r to Court you to his Arms.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Pernicious Traytor! what's thy Damn'd Deſign?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I mean to make you Queen of large Dominions.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Oh Heav'ns, the Villain does deride my griefs:
But if Thomazo's dead, I'le not ſurvive;
There's many ways to Death, and I'le find one.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Madam, on that account you need not do't,
For Prince Thomazo's well.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: O! tell me Friend,
One Truth before you die, how did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Why truly then, we left him juſt as faſt
As Heels could carry us! Faith, there's no coming
Within the length on's Sword: yet this I'le boaſt,
Though he out-fights us, we out-run him much.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Is the Prince ſafe then?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Yes, but I ly'd not,
For Ghoſtly Fathers laid hold on him,
And ſo we got the ſtart.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: You're honeſt men!
Lorenzo! Treat them firſt, then pay their Money—
But, do you hear—be ſure you Spice their Cups—

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I ſhall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Give them double Doſes.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Your Lordſhip is too bountiful.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Madam, the Mighty Sultan is your Slave:
To the Exalted State of Turkiſh Queen
My care is to advance you, think of that.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Sure thou art not half the Traytor thou would'ſt ſeem.

stage.hi: Enter Synan Baſſa, Dorello, and Mutanuope.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: My Converſation ever was at Court,
Though not i'th' higheſt Sphere, and Prince Thomazo
Has often honour'd me with his Commands:
But he's a Prince of ſuch a ſteddy temper,
'Tis not the Sultans Empire would Bribe him
To one diſloyal thought, much leſs Morea.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: I do believe you Sir; and that's the cauſe
I cannot find one man that dares attaque him,
Nor do I hope Succeſs, if you ſhall do't;
I only by it ſeek to gain ſome proofs
May ſhew my Prince my care has not bin wanting.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: Upon the word of a true Gentleman,
I'le break the matter to him—and return,
My Life and Liberty continuing ſafe,
To give you his full Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me,
You have ſome Secrets gain'd o'th' Chancellour
Muſt be kept private too.—

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: From all but him,
With whom I mainly treat, they ſhall, my Lord;
Nor ſhall he know them but on faithful promiſes
Of being private, and you may truſt his word.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: No generous mind can well ſuſpect another
Without ſome cauſe, and I ſee none in you;
And as a proof of my eſteem, I'le truſt you.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: Your Frankneſs binds me more than Sacraments,
And makes me bold to ask one Favour more,
That as you'd ſend the Prince this Boy agen,
He did eſteem him much.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Sir, I am ſorry
I muſt deny you this—But Sir, believe me,
This Boy is worth my Life; you do not know
Our Sultan—the leaſt breach of his Commands
Is Death inevitable. You heard him ſay
He'd have him made an Eunuch; I muſt do't,
Or never ſee his Face in ſafety more.
He likes him 'cauſe he is a Natural Mute;
He's properer for Secrets than the other.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: No, not at all my Lord, for I will tell you—

sp.speaker: Mutant.
sp.l: Make me an Eunuch! before I will be that,
I'le own I have both Tongue and Ears to boot.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange obſervance this you tell me of;
'Tis pity he was Mute—but come poor Child—
How's this?

stage.hi: Mutant. will not follow, Synan takes hold of him.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: I thought he gueſt at our Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: This mu •… not ſave you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mutant.
sp.l: O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Ha! do you delude me Sir?

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: No, on my Life!

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Sirrah! who taught you to diſſemble Dumbneſs?

sp.speaker: Mutant.
sp.l: I was a Spy, plac'd on Thomazo's Actions
By my Lord Chancellour.

sp.speaker: Dorell.
sp.l: O Monſtrous Subtilty!

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Then as thy puniſhment, I will aſſure thee,
Thy Tongue ſhall keep an Everlaſting Silence;
For I will ha'it cut out. Sir, follow me.

stage.hi: Enter Andrea, Lionello, Souldiers poyſon'd—doing mad things; ſome Cuffing, ſome Singing.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Obſerve this ſight, you'l ſay I am in earneſt,
When I declare I mean to make you Queen.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: What, you have made the Ruffians Drunk, 'it ſeems!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Aye, Dead Drunk; pray mark'em Madam.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: To be poyſon'd thus! to be ſent out of the World like
A Rat, by a Politick Whoremaſter.—Oh—oh—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Was this the double Doſe the Devil meant?
Sure 'twas a Cup of Wild-fire mixt in Hell.
Such Drink as this wou'd make Damnation double.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: Pray, pray Captain! Good Captain let's to pray'rs.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: It is too late for pray'rs—ten thouſand Devils
Are in my Entrals, tearing out my Soul.
Water! Water! to quench this Helliſh Fire.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Water, Water, Water, &c.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: See Lionello! See, the Devil's there.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Where? Where? I ſee him grinning now i'th' Shape
O'th' Chancellour.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Look! how he Laughs and Snickers; Ha, ha, ha,
A Woman-Devil too—there's Whores in Hell.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Aye, Whores! abundanee!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Let me have one then;
They're Coolers Lionello! Excellent Coollers,
And I'm exceeding Hot.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha; what Crotchets come into their dying Pates?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: How, dying Sir! in this Diſpairing State!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Yes truly, Madam. I take care they ſhan't
Spoil your Advancement by their future Prating.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I've heard and ſeen too much, and will no more.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A VVhore! a thouſand VVhores, good Lucifer,
For our Great Chancellour! Some VVhores, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: I'le Pimp no more for him! I'le ſee him firſt:
Let him be Flog'd, let him be Flog'd. VVhips, VVhips,
Let him have VVhips of Fire to Laſh his Soul.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: The Stinking Lord grows dry, and needs VVhips;
Then lend me one, good Devil, I will tear him.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: My Lord!
Theſe Letters come from Synan Baſſa.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: See there! the Chriſtian Slaves are paid their VVages.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: Give me my Gold, give me my Gold, Gold, Gold;
I'le Rob the Church no more elſe. Give me Gold.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Aye, give me Gold! I'le pay my VVhores moſt bravely,
She ſhall wear Smocks well Lac'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: Oh Heaven!

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: If there be Heav'n!
VVhich is the way, good Captain; I'le go thither.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Right before your Noſe.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: O Heav'ns! my Daughter, and Ʋdoxia both,
Are in the Turkiſh Camp—ſurpriz'd by theſe
In a miſtake. Ten thouſand Torments more
VVrack your Bodies here, and Souls hereafter.

sp.speaker: Lion.
sp.l: VVhat Screech-Owl's that? ha! what a ſight is this?
Then I am dying too! My Lord, look down,
All theſe loſt Souls will be requir'd of you;
They will, my Lord; and I can this foretel,
I'th' midſt of all your hopes you will find Death,
By Tortures worſe than ours. Some Mercy Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
