sp.l: Hell take thee for thy News; it meets an hour
Of ſuch Calamity, it makes Impreſſion;
See that their Bodies ſafely are beſtow'd.
VVould I had ne're begun to be thus ill,
It had been better much. Then I'd beſt change!
But how? I am gone too far to do that ſafely:
Then farewel Virtue, ſince it is too late,
By Ills on Ills I'le 'mount above my Fate.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Thomazo, Theop. and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: This is Prodigious! 20 great Ships
To Sail o're Land eight Miles, this threatens more
Than all they did before.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This Storm was made
Only t'amuſe us whilſt they lodg'd the Ships
Above the Chain; So to Beſiege us round
And cut off all Relief.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: That they'l now do;
Never 'till now we truly found the want
O'th' Chriſtian Ships I order'd to be ſtopt;
There was ſome Practice, which I ſhall find out,
Procur'd that diſobedience to thoſe orders;
All I find guilty certainly ſhall dye for't.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: He that advis'd their Sayling muſt be one then.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I do ſuſpect him moſt, but yet I can't
Safely, without clear proof, Arreſt his Perſon;
The Senate would Reſent it if I did.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: My Lord, No news o'th' Souldiers, or your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Surely they have convey'd 'em to the Turk?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I fear that moſt—But come, Let's go to Council.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Council may Cure the State; but cannot me:
This Loſs foretels my endleſs Miſery.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Thomazo makes the Guards ſo Vigilant,
Her leaſt Reſiſtance, Sir, would Ruine all.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Then She muſt be deluded by this Boy!
Think you he'll do't well?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Ne're doubt, my Lord,
He is by Nature fram'd for Roguery.

sp.speaker: Chan.
sp.l: Inſtruct him well; But to avoid detection,
Send him along with her—I muſt to Council.
My pretty Child, Do what Lorenzo bids thee
And thou ſhalt have my Favour.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Come Kecko—
What a ſad life is this to be confin'd
From Friends, or ſight of any Humane Creature,
But Cruel, unrelenting Murderers;
And ne're to change this Goal but for a worſe:
A Sultaneſs—a Strumpet—Ah Thomazo,
Hadſt thou been true, this Miſchief ne're had happen'd.

stage.hi: A Song without, after which Kecko comes in Playing.

l.hi: VEnus chanc'd to Love a Boy,
Young Adonis was her joy;
He once lept from off her Knee
To hunt and take an Humble-Bee,
Then the Bagg to her did bring,
She ſigh'd, and askt him for the Sting.
When he look'd on, ſaw her Eye
Drop a Tear, he ſtrait did cry,
Oh! forgive me, I will bring
A bigger and a longer Sting.
Smiling, ſhe cry'd, pretty Lad,
When that time comes, I'le be glad.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I ſee there ſtill is left ſome Innocence
To keep the World from ſinking. Pretty Boy,
Which way did'ſt thou get in?

sp.speaker: Kecko.
sp.l: I'le ſhew you Madam.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: This Child may prove an Angel-Guardian to me.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Thomazo, Cardinal, Chancellor, Theoph. as from Councel.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: This Inſolence o'th' Souldiers ſo debated
By the Senate firſt, and now by us in Councel,
Does ſpend that time might better be employed
For the ſafety of the whole,—firſt let the Senate
Provide but Mony ſpeedily to pay them,
Strickt Diſcipline will follow that of courſe.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Majeſty however may conſider
That theſe Debates are not without all cauſe,
I wiſh to Heav'n they were, with Tears I ſpeak,
To have our Children raviſh'd from our Armes;
Nay, torn from Altars in deſpite to Heav'n,
And all things, Sacred Law, Nature, and Religion,
To be made Proſtitutes to their vile Luſts!
To have a Lord o'th' Senate and the Councel,
Convey'd away and Murther'd; This brave Prince,
Forc'd to deſend his Sacred Perſon daily
By his own Courage, 'gainſt their Inſolence,
Not to ſpeak of Priſons broke, or reſcues made,
And all the leſſer miſchiefs hourly done!
If this be not worth a Senates grave advice,
What can be Sir?

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: My good Lord Chancellor,
I do believe all men will think my griefs
Muſt equal be to yours, the cauſe being ſo,
I'am ſure this wretched Life I would give up
To ſee my Daughter and her honour ſafe:
But yet I think her yours, and hundreds more
Not worth the time we vainly ſpend about them:
My Lord, by your advice amongſt the reſt
The Empire lies at ſtake: firſt think of that,
And mony 'tis, if any thing can ſave it,
All Councels that retard that, ſcarce are honeſt.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Honeſt! 'twas ſcarce well, ſaid the Senate ſitting,
I'm ſure of that, for they're of other minds,
And 'tis but fit we wait their Reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Certainly your Majeſty cannot do better
Then follow their advice; they're the great Council,
They repreſent the whole, what they conclude,
You may without th' leaſt fear of blame purſue.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Blame! my Lord Cardinal, you are not my ſubject,
And ſo perhaps do erre through Ignorance;
But good my Lord, learn this,—I give account
To none but Heav'n for any thing I do:
I take advice 'tis true, but ſtill am free
To act as I ſee cauſe,—Council does ceaſe
To wear that name when it can be Coercive;
So know my Lord, I fear no Earthly blame,
No, not the Popes. Then uſe ſome other word.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Sir, I ask Pardon if that word offended,
I can be ſorry too, but yet that ſhant
Make me neglect my Duty to the Pope,
Whom you were pleas'd to name with too much heed;
As I conceive, I have no bus'neſs here,
Except you think his Holineſs on Earth,
Heaven's Deligate.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: In Heavenly things I do;
In Earthly, though he has no more Dominions
Than what our Royal Predeceſſor gave him;
And if he ſeeks more here, 'tis Labour loſt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I'm glad his Eminennce hears this I ruth
From your own Sacred Mouth; he ſtill believ'd
None but my ſelf durſt boldly urge the Point,
My Enemies I'm ſure made him believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Highneſs I'm afraid miſtakes your friends,
Your beſt and trueſt Friends, for Enemies;
I humbly am afraid, I ſay, you do;
For I believe there's not a Grecian breaths,
But does admire you juſtly for your Virtues,
Your ſollid Prudence, Conſtancy and Vallour.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Spend not your breath my Lord, in long harangs
Of me, for all you can ſay, wont
Make my Opinion jump with yours
In your this Dayes debates.—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No certainly,
To urge the ſtop o'th' Empires main concern
For private Grievances, as if you did
Deſign the Turk ſhou'd win it,—this is Truth.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I'm ſorry that your Majeſty thinks ſo;
But I have hopes the Senate yet will clear me.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Thoſe hopes are Inſolent! I ſaid it Lord—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I hope, my Lord, my candid Actions will
Set me in former favour with my Prince,
And clear to all the World my Innocence;
So humbly begging Pardon, I'le retire.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I wiſh your Majeſty may do the beſt.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: This Chancellor, your Majeſty does ſind,
Diſturbs, if not betrays your weightyeſt Councils.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: He plainly does them both; yet at this juncture
It is not ſafe to take the Seals away,
For fear the Senate think their love to him
Does move me to it.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Let him keep them,
Without the Princes favour thoſe are uſeleſs.
But Sir, the time requires, that with reſolves
Becoming Majeſty, you preſs the Senate
For ſpeedy Aid, and till that's done, command
That no debate beſide be enter'd on.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: No Emperor, ever Raign'd, had a leſs mind▪
To place harſh Rules on Councils than my ſelf;
The Freedom of Debates ſhould be preſerv'd
If it were poſſible in every Council,
Much more in that of higheſt Dignity;
If not in time we ne're ſhould hear the Truth,
As theſe common Rules muſt be laid by;
New Exigents muſt make new Preſidents,
And ignorance only ſtill Cries out for old.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, your affairs are at the laſt extream;
The Senate if they pleaſe may help you much;
And I am confident the major part
Wou'd ſingly quit their lives to do you ſervice;
That which prevents them, are ſome ſubtle heads,
By ſpecious doubts and queſtions puzle them.
Your Reſolution muſt undo this Charm.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Brother, in this I do concur with you,
Nothing but their extreams ſhall make me ſo,
They'l either guide or force all I ſhall do.

stage.hi: Enter Irene in Mans Cloaths, with the Boy.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: THus far we are well; we've paſt two Courts of Guard:
Dear Child, how many more doſt think there is?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: There's but one more before we get toth' Court.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Sure this is not the way; although't be dark,
Yet I've ſome little gueſſe, and think theſe Lanes
Do rather lead toth' harbour then the Court.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, I'le warrant you, do but follow me,
I ſoon will make you ſafe.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo; that is the end of St. Sophia
Street. Child, thou miſtakes, this is the way I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: That muſt not be—who goes there?—
None ſpeak, who are you there I ſay?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Twas no body.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I'm ſure there was, it ſeem'd a Womans voice,
And comming from my Lord, I hope it is not
The beauteous Lady we had Pris'ner there,
Her loſſe would ruine him.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Come, come, there's no body; let's haſt home to bed.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: No, I will watch this Street for halfe an hour,
I'm ſure 'twas ſome body deſign'd to paſſe.

sp.speaker: Guard without.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Friends.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: What Friends?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Friends to the Guard and Servants to the Lord Chancellor.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Come before the Captain of the Watch.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: The Grand Round's coming; haſte! we're undone—

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I'le follow thee—but know not what I ſhun.

stage.hi: Enter Thomazo and Soldiers as in a Grand Round, with them Michael and Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: Our Lord's not come from Court, and we were going
To wait upon him there.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: The Councel did ſit late.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Your Highneſs has no commands to honour
Your humble Servants with.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: No, none at all.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Where are we now? I've follow'd thee ſo faſt,
I had not time t'obſerve which way we ran.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nor I, I'm ſure, nor know I what to do,
I've loſt my ſelf, and ſhall be Ruin'd by it,
I wiſh I ne're had medl'd.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: What ſay'ſt thou Child? Come, I will ſave thee harmleſs:
Let's knock at the next houſe and take a Guide.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, no, they all know me, that were the way
To be Surpriz'd, and carry'd to my Lords—
Stay you here, I'le ſearch about for the way.

sp.speaker: Trene.
sp.l: How terrible to me this darkneſs ſeems!
That and this Habit both do give me fear,
And yet they both muſt prove my greateſt Friends.
Unuſual things, though Innocent, amaze us.
I'm near the Strand: I hear the Water roar
As if the Waves ſought to o'recome the Shore;
This joyn'd with Solitude, the Night and Fear
Makes all my Danger double to appear;
But who are theſe?

stage.hi: Enter Michael and Lorenzo looking about.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: If ſhe be gone, we'l uſe the Boat our ſelves,
It is no ſtaving, ſhe'l betray us all.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange Diligence in Prince Thomazo,
To walk the Round himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: To meet with us in St. Sophia-ſtreet was damn'd
Unlucky too.

sp.speaker: Michael.
sp.l: Would that was all,
But thus to loſe our prize, makes me ſtark Mad,
Let's to the Barge, perhaps they may inform us.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Theſe are the Villains that the Round did ſtop,
And Prince Thomazo too it ſeems was there:
Oh! my unlucky Fear that made me fly
From ſuch a Sanctuary that was ſo near me,
Their words ſeem'd darkly to reflect on me,
And on a Boat; I hope I am not betray'd.
But where ſhould be the Boy, he ſtays thus long?
I am affraid, in ſeeking out his way,
He's ſlipt into the Sea: Heavens guard him from it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hiſt! hiſt!

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Here, here! oh, there has bin two men
Came talking by: Two of the Chancellors Servants,
They ſeem'd to ſpeak of me and of a Boat.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Which way went they?

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Down this Street.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That's our way; I now have found it out,
Come, let's make haſte—

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: No, let's go any way rather than that.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: We muſt go that, there is no other truly.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I tell thee, Child, I'le rather ſeek Thomazo,
He's on the Round, I wiſh I had not ſhun'd him;
Come, let's up this Street.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Stay a little!
What ſhall I do? how unlucky 'twas I went
That they ſhould miſs us thus,—I'de better kill her,
I'm ſure, than ſhe ſhould meet Thomazo,
That muſt not be then: but I will trifle time;
Perhaps they may return.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Come Child, what look'ſt thou for? Prithee let's go,
This way I'm ſure does lead to the higher ſtreet,
And that way to the Sea.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, I'm confident this is our way,
And I muſt go no other; Pray come then.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: This Boy Surprizes me,—I will go this way.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You ſhall not take my Cloaths along with you,
I am ſure of that, if you will needs be going,
Strip and deliver them firſt.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Prithee Child, let me perſwade thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, no, give me my Cloaths, and go where you will.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: You know I want my own, and they're much better;
Put up thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, no, go back toth' houſe, and take your Cloaths,
But on you ſhall not go if I han't mine.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I have a Sword too, and ſure, methinks his ſtrength
Should not be more than mine; Come, Prithee
Be rul'd, and go this way, I have a Sword elſe,
And twice the ſtrength of thee; but I am loth
To do thee hurt, if thou wilt put up thine.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: No, I will not, except you'l go this way.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Nay, then there's more than Childiſh thoughts
Does prompt the Boy: To this a greater ſear
Muſt drive away the leſs—
Come Child, be rul'd, I ſtill am loth to hurt thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay, if you come to that, do what you can,
You ſhall not ſteal my Cloaths:
I muſt gain time, yet I'm loth to hurt her.
sp.stage: They fight aukerdly, and at a great diſtance.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Boy, you ſee your Sword can do no good;
Then truſt my word, and go along with me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: If I had thought you'd ha' ſerv'd me thus,
I'd never have helpt you, that I wou'd not.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: How's this! They're here—
What, Men a quarrelling?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: No, on my life meer Boys,
Ripe Soldiers I'le be Sworn; what is the Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Let him tell it if he will.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: O! I am loſt, theſe are the Murderers,
The Boy will certainly diſcover me.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Young Gentlemen, here take your Swords agen;
What would your Quarrel be? Rivals in Love!

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ay, for a Paper Kite, or ſome ſuch thing:
What, will neither of you relate your Quarrel?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Our Quarrel was about the way to Court,
He ſaid 'twas that; and I affirm'd 'twas this.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Then he was in the wrong, and ought ask pardon.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I do with all my heart: Pray, Sir, forgive me;
What a good Boy is this that ſtill conceals me.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We juſt came both from Court,
Yet will go back a little way with you
To ſet you right, that you ſha'nt miſs it after.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I humbly thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: And ſo do I;
But I ſtill doubt this way, I know not why?

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: It was a ſtrange neglect you and your Father
Both made, in not diſcovering this Dorello
To be a Lord o'th' Council: I'm afraid
'Twill coſt his Head; but I have given him notice,
He is gone back; and on what Errand too.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: I hope his Wiſdom ſoon will find away
To clear himſelf, and place all guilt on him:
But good my Lord, how ſtands my great affair.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Madam, as you wou'd wiſh to morrow Night,
The Sultan does intend you for his Bed,
Therefore adorn your ſelf with all your Charms.

sp.speaker: Caliſta.
sp.l: My Lord, this Obligation is ſo great,
That no ſufficient thanks can be repay'd.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, but it may; for tho we Eunuchs
Cannot be Lovers, yet our other Paſſions
Grow more unruly by our loſs of that,
As Deprivation of one Senſe, does double
The Vigour of another: ſo Ambition
Oſt gives hopes, fears, fruition, and deſpair
To us, more violently then Lovers feel them,
Then when you ſhall poſſeſs the Sultans heart,
This paſſion of my Soul you may indulge.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Next pleaſing him, it ſhall be all my Study,
And let me be deſpis'd by the Great Sultan
That hour I fail to be your faithful Creature:
Thus I muſt talk till I poſſeſs my power,
Then I am free to act as I ſee cauſe.

stage.hi: Enter Mutan with a Letter which Synan reads.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Go, bring that Perſon in that brought this
Letter; Madam, 'tis from your Father.
Tell me Friends! how did the Youths you brought
Behave themſelves?

sp.speaker: Meſſeng.
sp.l: One Sir was quiet, to'ther ſhew'd a ſorrow
Approach'd near Madneſs, oft, if not prevented,
He had leapt over-board to drown himſelf;
Thus he continued 'till our Boat was boarded,
By one went hence to Town; in that there was
A Chriſtian the Boy knew, and whiſper'd with;
On which he did produce a large Commiſſion
Under the Sultans Seal, and ſign'd by you,
Pretending he had power to take him from us,
But all in vain; our Orders were too ſtrict,
So we reſus'd obedience, and have brought him.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: You have done well, keep them without a little,
This deſperate Youth he talks of is Irene,
And he that would have ſeiz'd her, is Dorello,
None elſe have had my paſs: What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Sir, if the Sultan ſees her, I am deſpis'd:
Her charming Beauty will eclipſe mine quite.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: But how ſhall I prevent it?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: If you would
Oblige me to the full, then tell the Sultan
That ſhe is loſt by'th' way: her Sex conceal'd,
As I perceive 'tis yet, will make the Story
Above all Contradiction, but by me,
And for my own ſake, I ſhall never clear it;
This way you may ſecure my happineſs,
And place about his Perſon your own Creature.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: I will devote my ſuture life to you,
And hazard all my Fortunes on your Game;
But how ſhall I conceal this charming Beauty.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Deliver her to me, as a Boy
Sent you by ſome miſtake, her ſears will then
Prompt her to keep conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Well, I'le prepare her—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Now baſe Thomazo, I'le Revenge thy ſcorns
Upon the Perſon of the lov'd Irene:
She and Ʋdexia both ſhall feel the ſinart
Of an inrag'd Love, led by deſpair,
Yet ſtill my powers ſecure, I muſt diſſemble:
This Synan Baſſa has a Soul too honeſt
To be Aſſaulted with my great Deſigns
'Till I'm above his Arts to keep me out,
But that once brought about; then my great Soul,
Shall freely have it's ſwing without controule.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Your Labour will not be much, Madam, this Boy
Sent me, I know not why, here I devote
To do you ſervice—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: My Lord I thank you,
A pretty Boy indeed; your name ſweet Youth.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: I had not time to make it! Oh my Fate!
To be condemn'd a Slave to her I hate.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: What are your Bluſhes, Feare, or Modeſty,
Diſpence with both at preſent; tell your Name:

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: My Name's Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Heaven's ſhe mocks me!
But oh my Rage, be ſtill till I can feaſt Thee!
Where were you Bred? and who did you belong to?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: I've hardly wit enough to anſwer; Madam,
My over tender Friends childiſhly Bred me,
And I'm afraid 'twill Kill my Aged Father,
To find that I am loſt: If you have goodneſs
But equal to your Beauty, 'tis exceſſive,
And ſure a juſt Requeſt you can't deny.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: It may be not, but tell me what it is,
Your Complement does ſtrongly plead for you.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Madam, it is you would prevent the trouble
An unexperienc'd Boy will hourly give you,
And ſend me back agen to my poor Father.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: That muſt not be, you are too fair to part with;
I like theſe Childiſh looks; This pretty Face
Muſt not Adorn it ſelf with Bluſhes thus,
They do aſſault a heart too haſtily;
Part with ſuch ſweetneſs! Every word that begs it
Is a new Charm to ſtrengthen a Denyal;
I'le fetch a Glaſs, we will compare our Faces.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: It is no wonder Prince Thomazo gain'd her
Upon his firſt addreſs, ſince ſhe can thus
Court me, yet think me all the while a Boy.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Come hither pretty Rogue. That Noſe of thine
Would match this Face much better, Thoſe Plump lips
Methinks I cou'd Steal too—I needs muſt kiſs 'em—

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Good Madam, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: So very Coy!
That pretty Chin I like—but for my Eye
I wou'd keep that, my Eye-brows too and Forehead.
Betwixt thy Face and mine might ſure be made
A Beauty that wou'd Captivate all Hearts;
Let's try to make one ſuch. Thy Innocence
Can do no harm in Bed; come thou and I
Wont part till both get better Bed-fellows.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Prodigious Impudence! This goes beyond
The worſt invented Stories of our Sex. Ha!

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Perhaps Irene will own her ſelf to you,
To me ſhe ſeems all man, and Courts me too.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Pardon me, Madam, that I durſt not own
A Perſon I wiſht loſt to the whole World.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: What to Thomazo?

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Las, that Name I took
In too much haſte, I know not what I ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: But can this be Irene?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Dear Friend, it is,
The much ſurpriz'd Irene to meet you here.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Did not Dorello tell you of us both?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: How Madam, can you know he met with me?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: I do forget my ſelf, you came but now.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: But what in this diſguiſe has brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: How we're all here, I know not, but Caliſta,
I fear your Father has been much too blame.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: But I'le amend his Fault, by keeping you
From being ſeen by any perſon living,
'Till you are ſafe got back.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: If this prove true,
Her worth will my Averſion quite ſubdue.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor and Chancellor Diſcourſing earneſtly.

sp.speaker: Emperor.
sp.l: This to my Reaſon ſeems incredible,
Yet to my ſence is plain.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Your Majeſty
Will ſure perceive my Innocence by this,
And what juſt grounds I had for all my Fears.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I know not what to think, but ſure he cannot
Be ſo unnatural, as this does ſpeak him:
Ill men begin at firſt with petty Crimes,
And dare not by degrees lanch forth to great.
But he at one great leap from good to bad,
Seems to love miſchief in Extremity,
And ſcorn to mount it's top by graduation.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sir, to be near, and yet but near a Crown,
In Souls like his move ſtrong Agitations.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What ſhall I ſay to it?—I cannot think—
But he will ſoon be here—Dorello too—
I ſcarce have Faith enough to doubt of his,
But to believe an only Brother Traitor,
And Traytor to this height—I cannot do't—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sir, as you pleaſe for that. I charge him not—
Alas he is too great for me to Cope with,
But I had rather much his Power ſhould Cruſh me;
Ay! Cruſh me into nothing—then that you
Who are my Soveraign Lord, and ſuch an one
To whom I owe all that is Noble in me,
Shou'd ſeem to hazard life, and Empire both,
By any fears of mine—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What ſhall I do?
Cannot a Prince be merciful and ſafe?
'Tis very hard I find—this wicked Age
Does almoſt think there's no ſuch thing as goodneſs,
And villifie all Perſons that profeſs it;
If Princes pardon Crimes they count it weakneſs,
And if they puniſh them 'tis Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, did you ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Ay Thomazo!
But 'tis to tell you that which does amaze
Far more then Anger me; Cannot you gueſs
At what the matter is, and ſpare my Tongue
The trouble to declare ſuch unkind things;
I wiſh you would Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your Majeſty
Shall not find it hard to know the greateſt ſecret
My mind can labour with.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Then tell me Brother,
Have not ſome late tranſactions done by you,
Or by Dorello's Miniſtry at leaſt,
Bin of that Nature, well nigh cauſe my Anger.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Commented on by Enemies they may,
And I ſuſpect no Friend was ſo officious
To tell you my deſign.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I do perceive
I'm ſome reſtraint upon the Princes Candor,
Therefore ſhall take my leave.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: And can you Brother
Wiſh Empire without Glory?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I know not
What 'tis your words do tend to? All I know
Or have tranſacted that might trouble you,
Has not the leaſt Reflections towards Empire.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Then tell your Reaſons Brother.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, the Cauſe
I kept my Paſſion ſecret, was for fear
Some ſcruples in your own or Senates Breaſts
Might have prevented that, which when once done,
I knew you ſoon wou'd Pardon.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Pardon Brother,
What, think you I'm ſo tame to Pardon Treaſons,
That ware ſo black a Viſage?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sure no Law
Does limit my free choice of any Wife,
Under ſo high a Penalty as Treaſon;
But if there was, the Merit of Irene
Wou'd ſtrongly plead I'm ſure in my excuſe.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: This Love you own, I never did diſlike,
Though I ſuſpected it; but 'tis not that
Has brought me to this Parly, but worſe matters.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I am ignorant of any thing,
Beſides my hopeleſs Love can move your Anger.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Nay, Brother, you ſhall ſee 'tis not ſlight matters
That have oblig'd me to this unkind Parly.
Bring in that fellow there—friend, tell your Story.

sp.speaker: Meſſeng.
sp.l: Sir, as I ſaid before, being employ'd
Toth' Turkiſh Camp about Intelligence,
I there have heard them ſay, that Prince Thomazo
Muſt be Morea's King, and that this Town
On that condition, he will ſoon give up.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, can you credit Slaves, hir'd to accuſe me,
Of ſuch impoſſible deſigns as theſe?
Villain! who has ſuborn'd you to ſay this?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Be patient till you hear his Story out.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I ſooner might be patient when hot Pincers
Were tearing off my Fleſh.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: But I commend you.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then ſilent Sir as Death, I'le hear my honour
Be blaſted by his Breath—and never murmur,
No Sheep ſhall fall more tamely Sir then I.
Friend, ſay all that the Chancellor has taught you.

sp.speaker: Meſſeng.
sp.l: Sir, what I've ſaid, and what I am to ſay,
My Senſes all muſt Witneſs is moſt true,
Though in the leaſt I do not accuſe your Highneſs;
What I have ſaid, I heard i'th' Turkiſh Camp:
I did—and what I ſaw there, is to follow—
Which is that oft at Synan Baſſa's Tent,
I've ſeen the Lord Dorello in great favour,
And Courted by the Baſſa, but laſt Night
He did come back to Town in a diſguiſe;
For meeting in their Fleet we boarded Boats,
And though he knew not me, yet I did him;
I ſaw him there produce a large Commiſſion,
And ſhew it to the Turkiſh Admiral,
By which he had full power to cloſe with you.
This Sir is true, as I have proof enough.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Return to your Confinement for a while,
You nor your Fellows ſha'nt be long reſtram'd;
What think you of this Brother.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I think
That Vertue which you Worſhip proves an Idol,
An empty name, leſs ſollid then a ſhaddow:
Oh deep unfathom'd Vilanies of State!
Through what ſtrange Mazes do you wind your ſelves,
That honeſt men cannot find Clews to trace you.—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What a ſad Fate have Princes that are born
To bare the Fate of ſinking Monarchy;
Thoſe actions which we judge will prop it moſt,
Produce its ſpeedier Ruin: Faction grows
And ſpreads it ſelf through Councel, Court, and Notion,
And nothing can be heard but accuſations,
Theſe when we wou'd Unite for common good,
They ſay we Cheriſh for our private ſafety;
If we believe them all, then none are honeſt;
If we give Ear to none, all will grow angry;
So whether we're ſevere or moderate,
Our Glory's hid i'th' Ruin of the State.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, I have thought upon't, all this ſeems falſe,
But how to prove it ſo, I cannot gueſs.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Brother, I'le ſay no more but only this,
Act as you pleaſe, I n're can be unkind.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What worth the keeping life for now is left?
I am ſtript of all that's Dear, Friend, Miſtriſs, Brother,
And of my Honour too!—why live I then?
Becauſe I am a Chriſtian! Surely though
That cou'd at the firſt teach Contradictions,
What were moſt Martyrs but Self-Homicide?
What ſevere Hermit too but ſhortens life,
Why then 'tis plain I'm Maſter of my ſelf.
By beſt Rules of our Philoſophy:—
But ſome will hold 'tis Cowardize to die
For fear of Miſery!—Why then I'le live;
Yet ſcarce my ſelf, my ſelf alive ſhall know:
In ſtrict retirement my few hours will ſpend,
And by ſharp Abſtinence my life will end.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Theophilus, Chancellor, Cardinal, and Juſtiniano, who kneels and Kiſses the Emperors hand.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Sir, I with thanks receive my Liberty,
And ſhall diſcharge the Duty of my place,
With all the Zeal that may be ſince I hear
You have laid by the Prince.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: My Lord, I wiſh
You'd place a greater Guard upon your words;
It is not I, but my unlucky Stars
Have for the Empires ruine laid him by.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Sir, you ſhall ſee it's ſtronger prop
If you will find away to pay my men.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: My Lord, you do offend his Majeſty,
In ſpeaking of the Prince with ſuch contempt;
You had beſt attend your Charge, and leave to me
The getting of your Pay: The Emperor
Is put upon a project to get Mony
And you ſhall find your ſhare.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: My Lord, my men
Wont Fight one ſtroak without it, that I tell you.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord, no more, Your Majeſty
Should not regard his Folly but his Courage.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Courage! Each private Soldier may have that,
'Tis Conduct only makes a General;
And I ſuſpect his much, for all your Pray'rs;
But I'le not long endure his Inſolence,
I'le rather hazard all on my own perſon.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: What means your Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Why Fame does ſay,
This Sultan Mahomet's a Valiant Prince;
I'le try, if he'l on ſingle Combat ſtake
The Fortune of this War.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Cardinal.
sp.l: Perhaps
You have not well conſider'd that deſign;
Your Majeſty in ſuch a weighty Cauſe
Muſt ask advice of Piety not Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: My Lord, you ſpeak as if ſtrong Appetite
Did make me ſeek this Combat for a pleaſure,
But I'le aſſure you 'tis on no ſuch Cauſe:
Thank Heav'n I dare, but do not love to fight.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: No Sir, nor muſt not ſingly; Heaven's ſtrict Laws
Deliver'd by the Church, does quite forbid
All Duells under pain of higheſt cenſure.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Surely, when Heav'n gave Sacred Characters
To Clergy men; it did not then diveſt
The reſt of Mankind of the uſe of Reaſon;
Did it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: No, not of common Sir.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Common! I underſtand no ſuch diſtinction;
Reaſon is Reaſon, and that does plainly ſay,
If I i'th' head of Thouſands may make War,
And hazard both my own and others lives,
I ſure much more, may ſingly do the ſame.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Not without diſpenſation from the Pope,
As humbly I conceive.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Pope, good Man!
No Diſpenſations from his Officers,
'Tis they muſt have a Fee: Theſe tricks of Rome,
Of firſt forbidding, then diſpenſing things,
Has Rob'd it of the Reverence once it had,
From beſt Adviſers to Mens Conſciences;
They now are grown to be their Torturers,
Things in themſelves indifferent they make ſin;
And real ſins they dare give leave to act:
A man may be a Saint and Traitor both,
When Diſpenſation frees him from his Oath.
But trouble not your ſelf Lord Cardinal,
I'le ask the Sultans Diſpenſation only,
If he conſents, I'le not refuſe the Fight.
What have you ſeen him Doctor?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Sir, I find,
Except you Majeſty in perſon goes,
His Servants dare not let him be diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How do they ſay he is?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: They do believe,
As I have ſaid; it is a Lunacy
Sprung from an over-tender ſence of Honour;
But ſtill I'd undertake on pain of Death,
Were I but few days with him, I wou'd awe him.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Come, we'l go viſit him, his Health wou'd bring
Me Vigour to our ne're expiring power,

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n he be but Mad, I'le never fear
This cheating Quack from Perſia e're can cure him:
He'l ſooner Poiſon him I'le undertake,
And that part of his Art I'le undertake,
And that part of his Art I'le try him in
If I can fix him well—but ſtay this Combat
The Emperor deſigns, and I do fear
The Sultan may accept in thirſt of Glory
Muſt be prevented; 'tis too much to ſtake
My utmoſt certain hopes upon one Throw
But ſure I need not fear, the fair Irene
Will keep him from that Danger.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Noble Sir,
New Letters from the Baſsa, ſay his Maſter
Doth Dote ſo much, that he forbears all action.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: How's this? I fear the Love he bares Irene
May make him raiſe the Siege.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I fear it too.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Well, ſomething muſt be done that may prevent it,
Can you learn nothing yet of this Dorello?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Not any thing, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sure he walks Inviſible! That Danger
Did threaten moſt of all, and yet my Stats
Has brought me off with Triumph.—
But ſtay!—The Emperor deſigns to Beg
Something by way of Loan o'th' Citizens;
He'l find them Curſed free! Ha! ha! ha! a Beggar Prince
Is ſuch a Contradiction—but I'le go
And ſee the ſport, I hope I ſhall be able
To keep my ſelf from down right laughing at him.

stage.hi: Enter Thomazo, Solus with a Book in his hand.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: It cannot be but all that they ſay's Chymera,
There is no ſollid Truth in all this ſtuff;
'Tis meerly words: They'r Sinowy Sillogiſmes
By which they puzle both themſelves and us,
Are perfect Ropes of Sand: If we'l be Fools
To grant their firſt Conceptions, then they'l prove
The Conſequence muſt needs be this or that.
Grant me ſays one an Immaterial Giant,
That does reſide in Immaterial place,
I'le prove he turns the Primum Mobile,
And that turn all things elſe about the Globe:
Then ſtarts another up, and he conceives,
That Immaterial Being is abſurd;
Strait brings his Giant in to do his Tricks
On good Material Leggs—then ſhews a Storm
Produc'd by a ſlight cold matter had got,
Which made it Sneeze—all comes to ſuch like ſtuff,
Avant ſubſtantial thick Aegyptian darkneſs,
Rank miſt of words be gone; there's nothing true,
No nothing: Good and Ill are only Names
Stampt by our Intereſts; farewell all Books,
I'le Study nothing but my Miſery,
And how to Die apace. Ah Mighty Sir,
And may I not have leave to do that neither,
'Tis all I beg; you once were a kind Brother.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I've not a thought but ſpeaks me kind as ever.
Here is a Learned Doctor.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What to do?
I want no health—If you have skill, feel here,
Does not my Heart keep it's Pulſation right,
As right as ever, though it is juſt a breaking;
Come wave your profit once and ſpeak the Truth.
Am not I well in health?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Your Highneſs is
In what the Bloods concern'd.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Oh, let alone
The inward man: That goes beyond your Tools,
Your Probe's not long enough to Tent my Soul:
Sir, on my Knees I beg I may be private.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: From all but this one man, Brother you ſhall—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then ſince I muſt be Plagu'd with converſation,
I'le ask ſome queſtions: How go things i'th' Senate?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Their obſtinacy forc'd me to diſmiſs them.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: That was a prudent ſtep, but how the Siege?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Turks like loving Neighbours ſeem moſt quiet.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: They then expect ſome Revolution here!
Lord Cardinal, when come our helps from Rome?
When I go next abroad,—nay, my good Lord,
I've anſwer'd now my ſelf,—your Majeſty,
I hope, will free me now from all but him.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Study your health, dear Brother, till you're well,
My Self and Empire both do languiſh in you.

stage.hi: Exeunt Manent Thom. and Dor. who pulls off his Beard.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Come Sir, to work, have you a Doſe of Opium,
For I want Sleep extreamly,—Ha—Dorello.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Ah Sir! Can you endure a Traytors Breath;
For ſo State Pamplets, and the Ballets call me;
For what I do not know, except it be,
That I know ſome are ſuch, I muſt not name;
But I have ſecrets Sir that will amaze you.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not more then does your Preſence in this manner;
Sure I'm deceiv'd,—on with your Beard again,
So,—now I ſee it only was my Fancy:
But where's Dorello gone?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ah, Noble Sir,
I fear you are not ſo well as I did hope.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: It is Dorello's voice too,—Ah dear Friend,
Wonder not I ſeem'd Craz'd: Alas, Irene,
Is Murder'd I believe, or loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: No Sir, She is not Dead, though I muſt fear,
That as you gueſs ſhe may be loſt for ever.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Not Dead! how know you that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I've ſeen her Sir,
And She's i'th' Turkiſh Camp from whence I came.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: From thence I'le preſently go Reſcue her.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: He is too near Diſtraction to be told
Irene's the Sultans Miſtriſs; but I'le go
And humour all his fancies till he ſleeps,
Perhaps ſome reſt will make him fit for Council.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Chancellor, Cardinal, Attendants and Rabble. Michael.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Their Obſtinacy makes things deſperate:
What's to be done my Lord?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Try a few more, here comes an Alderman.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Friend, you are Rich, I'm told, and therefore ſhou'd
Spare ſomething of it for your Countries ſafety;
Nay, for your own, your Wife and Childrens too;
For they and all you have lies now at ſtake.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.l: Your Majeſty is misinform'd of me;
I Rich! alas Sir, I am very poor.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Conſider Friend, who 'tis that goes a Begging,
Your careful Emperor himſelf in Perſon.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Your much diſtreſs'd Prince, conſider that,
Give ſomething Sir, and Heav'n will ſure reward it.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Friend, 'Tis not for my ſelf I ask! Heaven knows
That was't not for you my loving People,
I'd ſooner die then undergo this Shame:
Come Sir, be liberal, that others may
By your Example lend their mony freely.
That ſo the Soldiers paid, may boldly Fight,
And here I promiſe on my Royal Word,
That what you lend I'le faithfully repay
As ſoon as Peace has open'd Trade again.

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.l: This way of borrowing Sir, I fear's Illegal
Without the Senates leave,—and I'd be loath
To break the Law, and make bad Preſidents
That might infringe the Liberty o'th' Subject.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Ay! there's the Argument that choaks them all.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How ſtrangly Friend you do miſtake the Law,
Am I in worſe condition than a Subject?
Who wanting mony borrows any where;
Nay, what I borrow, I by force might take
At ſuch a time as this—a Law there is,
A Narural Law of Pow'r it may be call'd,
Which gives the Prince aright to every thing
He thinks may keep the Common-wealth from ſinking,
And this no other Law can Abrogate—

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.l: My Council does inform me otherwiſe,
And I ſhall take his word—Except my Lord,
You'l give your hand upon't he's in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Good Friend forbare, I am no Advocate
That ſigns my hand to every Caſe that's put:
His Majeſty expects your anſwer Sir.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! what Mock State is this?

sp.speaker: Alder.
sp.l: Your Majeſty
Muſt pardon me, for I can ſpare no Mony.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: 'Tis labour loſt, Heav'n ſurely binds their Eyes
To their Deſtruction; but I find, my Lord,
That you concur with their falſe arguing.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: The times are dangerous Sir, I dare not ſpeak
Except in private Council—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Princes may
By me be warn'd of two much Lenity;
The Rabble is a Jade, muſt feel her Rider,
'Tis not ſoft taps I ſee, but whips muſt rule her,
Humility moves none but generous Souls.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Was I not obſtinate to ſee Irene,
I ſcarce could let this Traytor live a Moment.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Good Sir, let me intreat you to deſiſt
From that ſo dangerous and vain attempt.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Dorello, ſay no more, I'm reſolv'd
To ſhew her I was true, though ſhe's not ſo;
And ſhou'd Death wait me in the Turkiſh Camp,
Yet I wou'd go,—ſee! how the Traytor laughs—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I put him on this project for his Ruin;
It was a ſubtle Myne, I knew, when ſprung,
Wou'd blow up all that little power he had:
An humble Prince makes Subjects Inſolent,
Then what does Begging do,—ha, ha, ha, honeſt Michael,
Go watch how he ſucceeds, and bring me word.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I muſt Alarm him—
His Soul is much too jocund for a Traytors;
My Lord, I have a mind to give allay
To your exceſſive laughter—where's Irene?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your Daughter too, Ʋdoxia and Dorello,
What? you to ſave their lives, have ſent them hence,
What punctual day Sir, muſt the Town be took?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sure Slave you know me not, you dare talk thus!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Yes, you are he, that by the help of Souldiers,
Did break the Sanctuary!—then for Reward,
Beſtow'd a Doſe of Poiſon on your Slaves;
You thought their Dying too a pleaſant ſight.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: What Devil canſt thou be that dar'ſt accuſe
Of Crimes ſo falſe as theſe?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I cannot ſtay at preſent now to prove them;
But in good time I may; i'th' Interim
I'le ſtep and tell your Daughter y'are a Traytor.
Have you no ſervice to the Eunuch Baſſa,
I'le kiſs his hands e're long—

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Ho! Michael!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If you'd prolong your life one day or two,
You may by being Silent; but if not,
This is your lateſt Moment.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Sure this muſt be
Some of Dorello's Inſtruments in Town.
My Ruin is contriv'd, I plainly ſee,
And I muſt be as quick in my preventions.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: The Begging Emperor has but ill ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Curſe on him, we have worſe, all is betray'd;
I've bin attaqu'd by one that knows Dorello,
And every thing by him that we have done.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Can this be poſſible, and we not find him;
I hop'd he had bin drown'd in his coming.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: No, all my Starrs grow dull of late; I think
They take no care of me, or my deſignes,
But ſtill my Plots are ſpoil'd by Countermines.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: THe Baſſa's Kindneſs to me ſtill Continues,
Nay, rather is increas'd by knowing me.
But yet I can't prevail to ſee the Ladies.

stage.hi: Enter Mutantrope, They ſign to one another.

sp.l: But ſee your little Traitor,—is your Tongue
Out out?—it is no matter, you deſerv'd it—
Nay, you do well, to own your fault,
There is no truſting ſuch a Rogue as you.
If I had any buſineſs—wou'd you indeed—
Then let me ſee Ʋdoxia, or Caliſta—
How! Caliſta in ſuch favour! where's Irene then▪
Thou art a lying Rogue, I ſtill perceive—
Oh Villain, dar'ſt thou ſwear ſo falſe a thing?
As that the Sultan does not know Irene?—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Can only ſuch a Traitor ſpeak the truth?
And all Man-kind be lyars? yet, methinks
The vertue of Irene, does make me hope it.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: If this you ſwear, be true, then bring my Friend
And me to ſee Irene—If you're forſworn
Expect a greater judgment then you have—
Well, wee'l try your faith.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: The Boy is ſtrangly earneſt; ſure he cannot
Be ſuch a Villain to invent all this?
'Tis poſſible the ſubtle Chancellor
Contriv'd, that Fame might ſay it was Irene,
Leſt his Intelligence might be ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: I can't tell, what to think; there's no deſign
The Boy can have—is worth his Perjury,
Except he wholly does delight in Falſe-hood.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: To ſee Irene, and ſee her true, will be
Some few Degrees beyond felicitie.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: She threatens now: what a rank Aſs was I
To bring ambitious Beauty 'bout my Prince,
This Poiſon is for Irene—
I'm confident,—but Lady look about you,
We Stateſmen have our tricks; 'tis well I did not
Inform her Father that it was her ſelf,
And not the fair Irene the Sultan dotes on,
Did he but know it, we ſoon ſhould have bin here:
His Politick Pate wou'd ſtill Solicite Bowſtrings
Might be preſented us, that vacant places
Might be diſpos'd by him,—but to his greif,
Both he and all men elſe, think 'tis Irene.

stage.hi: Enter Caliſta, Irene, Udoxia, and Mutes, one Carrying a Cup of Poiſon, th' other Bowſtrings.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: No! I'le cut off my fears, their hopes and thine
All at one blow.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Conſider but the Crime!

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: No Synan, you miſtake that charming Face
Which in dead colours firſt bewitch'd my Lord,
Shall not remain for you to ſhew a line,
From that deſign Springs all your Piety.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: If you fear that, then ſpare this other Lady;
Why Madam, muſt ſhe dye?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: For ſweet revenge,
She did upbraid me, with my Fathers Nature
And now ſhe'l find I have it thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: I will not loſe a Pray'r to ask thee Mercy,
Nor will I live after Irene is Dead.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: You ſhall never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Ah Caliſta!
Think of the pleaſant hours we three have ſpent
In Childiſh ſports together,—call to mind
How both of us have ſtrove which moſt ſhou'd pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Plead not our wanton Childiſh Tales to me,
I am a Woman, and do ſee the Danger
Of that bewitching Beauty you have got,
Therefore make haſte and chuſe your way of dying.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Save but Ʋdoxia's life, I'le call that Mercy,
And with my dying Breath beg pardon for you.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Irene, ne're ſpeak of that, give me the Cup,
I do defie all kindneſs from the Monſter
Except you ſhare it too—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Bravely Reſ lv'd!
But do not drink it all, one half will ſerve;
I try'd it on a Slave, and he dy'd calmly,
Made no ill Faces as ſome people do.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Come then, let's take our everlaſting leaves
Of all our Sorrows here,—my thoughts begin
To prompt me it is brave to leave this world,
And all it's flattering, falſe, and painted joys,
Which do allure to real Miſeries.
Ʋdoxia, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Farewel Dorello.

stage.hi: She drinks and gives the Cup to Irene.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: And farewel now for ever my Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Curſe on his Name, it ſtaggers me a little;
But Love Adieu! and Tryumph my Revenge!
In thy firſt Conqueſt—Farewel Play-fellows.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Sure 'tis ſome Bodied Fury this, not Wonman;
Ladies, you'l find your Deaths ſteal gently on you
Like a ſoft Sleep: but yet to ſhew I wou'd
Do any thing was in my power to ſerve you,
I'le ſend the little Traytor, Mutantrope
To find Dorello out, and bring him to you.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: May Heav'n reward your Charity, my Lord,
It is the only thing I'd wiſh on Earth.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: You ſhall not fail of that—now Muſtapha,
Our Plot is Ripe to ruine this Medea.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Whither, dear Friend, are thou and I a going?

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: To Heaven Irene.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Heav'n is a great way off,
And though I doubt not, we ſhall ſoon reach thither,
Yet Nature ſhudders at the world of Miles

That Fancy ſays is thither—Ah
Ʋdoxia—
I hope we ſhall know one another there.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: I hope ſoo too—yet, what the pleaſure is
Which happy Souls enjoy, I cannot gueſs,
But ſure it won't be any thing like thoſe
We do enjoy on Earth.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Ay, there's the fright;
Methinks we're about to loſe our ſelves,
And change to ſomething elſe. Tho' what we know not?
But we ſhall ne're be We again I fear.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Yet this we're certain of we can't be worſe.

stage.hi: Enter Mutantrope, and obſerves them, then Exit.

sp.l: But ſee the Boy! I hope Dorello's coming.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: It makes me happy I'm in your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vdox.
sp.l: I'le own that nought on Earth could be ſo welcome.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Nor to me neither except Prince Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: That word in ſpight of Fortune makes me happy.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: Ah! do I ſee you Sir? Then welcome Death—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How's this! Irene! paleneſs ſits on her lips.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: The ſudden Joy o'recame her—give her Breath,
She'l come to her ſelf—

sp.speaker: Vdox.
sp.l: Never on Earth.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What dreadful word is that? it pierc'd my Soul!

sp.speaker: Vdox.
sp.l: The ſtrange Surprize did make the Poiſon work.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Poiſon!

sp.speaker: Vdox.
sp.l: Ay Sir, Caliſta Poiſon'd her.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Ah Horrid Deed! but ſee the Prince Sir, Sir,
I fear his Soul's not proof againſt this blow.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Irene ſo Angry, that ſhe will not ſpeak!
Ha! Poiſon! Never! I will not have Caliſta,
Her Father is a Traytor—but Irene
Is the great Sultans Miſtriſs,—Is ſhe ſo?
Then I'le turn Hermit in a Grove of Willows,
Berrys of Baleful Ivy ſhall be my Food,
And the Drink nothing elſe but my own Tears!
For fair Irene is falſe.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Ah dire miſhap,
His ſcarce Cur'd Lunacy agen returns:
Great Sir, Irene is Vertuous—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Then I'le have her.
I will my Self deſtroy the Sultans Army,
And Reſcue my Irene—to horſe—to horſe
Draw up the Guards and follow,—ſound a Charge—
What do you Run you Dogs—

stage.hi: Draws & exiturus, is held by Dorello.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Oh, good Sir ſtay—
Diſcover'd once, he will be loſt for ever—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What are you that take me Priſoner?
I won't have Quarter now Irene is loſt.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Look on me Sir! do not you know Dorello?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! where's Irene? Oh! there, She's there—
Have I recover'd her?—I thank you all—
You have Fought bravely—you ſhall all be Knighted.
But won't Irene ſpeak to her own Thomazo?
Pardon me, Madam,—by all my Love I thought
'Twas you I ſhou'd have Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Ah poor Prince!
Dorello, look to him—but if you can
Procure our Bodies Chriſtian Funerals,
I know hers does, and I hope mine deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: What mean you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: I find the Poiſon works on me apace.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: What are you poyſon'd too!

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Ay Sir, Caliſta
Was kind in that, to let us Die together.
I can no more! Farewel, my dear Dorello.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: I envy not the Prince! why do not I
Learn the ſame Art to loſe my greif in Madneſs.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: What men are theſe, ſeize on them; ha! Thomazo
Dorello too!

stage.hi: They ſeize them, Thom. ſtands amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Ah thou curſed Monſter!
What Devil taught thee all this Cruelty?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: I learn't it of that Prince, he taught me firſt
To find my Nature bad—I elſe had liv'd
A puling vertue, ſtill frighted with tales
Of Hell and Devils, with other ſilly Bug-bears;
But ſeeing him the ſtout and brave Thomazo,
The Wiſe, Juſt, Generous, and great Thomazo,
Take pleaſure to betray a harmleſs Maid:
This taught me rage, and rag'd inſtill'd revenge,
Which made me do this petty triffling miſcheif;
But that's not half enough, ſince above my hopes,
You two are fallen thus into my hands.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Ay, dare thy worſt; as for that noble Prince,
Were he but ſafe, Death were to me ſavour.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Nay, you ſhall both together! Slaves your ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Though I'm a Priſoner; I'le
Wear no Chaines but thoſe of faire Irene!

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Irene is Poiſon'd!
Poiſon'd moſt Noble Prince, by this damn'd Monſter.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis the Devil Dorello, 'tis the Devil:
He has Caliſta's ſhape, but 'tis a Devil,
He cannot hurt me though, for I deſy him;
Ha, ha, ha,—ſee! how the Devil weeps
Becauſe he cannot get his will to hurt us.
VVe are too honeſt for his Miſchief,—let me go,
I'le make him vaniſh with a Vengeance hence.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Oh! I could chide my Eyes for ſhewing greif,
Tho' tis a Killing ſight.—Thomazo is Mad!
How came he thus Dorello?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Can you ask?
And ſee Irene lie Murder'd there by you?

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Oh I wou'd rail and call him if I cou'd,
Ungrateful, baſe Thomazo. But this ſight
Renews agen my Love, and ſtops my Mouth.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Talk not of Love at all, much leſs for him,
That is too good a Paſſion for thy Soul,
And he a Cauſe too Noble.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Ah Dorello!
Judge but from whence proceeds this Flood of Tears!

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: They're ſuch as Crocodiles by Nilus ſhed.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Nay, rather ſuch as once Medea did,
When ſhe diſpers'd her tender Brothers limbs;
Love taught her Cruelty, and I perceive
'Twas that, and not Revenge has Murder'd theſe.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: If cruel hearts, like yours, be capable
Of Love, yet all you have the Sultan claims.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: The Sultans Title ſprung from my Ambition,
But now that Paſſions cloy'd, and Love returns.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Madam, why do you pauſe? pray give me death,
Vdoxia chides my ſloath for ſtaying thus.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! Sir! I am no Traytor! I'm your Brother,
Ask Dorello if the Dam'd Chancellor
Be not the Mighty Traytor of your State—
But ſee his Daughter—She ſhall be Sultaneſs.—
I will have none of her—She is a Monſter—
See ſee—how ſhe's beſmear'd with Blood,
But where's Irene—Alas! She's angry—Ah me—
I will have none but her—

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Alas poor Prince!
The fair Irene is Murder'd by Caliſta.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ha! Murder'd! Irene Murder'd—then Calista
Shall be torn Limb from Limb by horrid Devils!
Her Soul ſhall turn that fatal Bird of Night,
With Crokes and Crokes for ſad departing Souls.

l.hi: IN Caves full of Sculls, and rotten old Bones,
She Sighs in the Day-time, and in the Night Groans.
'Mongst Ghoſts of the Guilty, for ever She'l howle,
And in Beds ſill'd with Serpents eternally Role.
But I and Irene will be Merry,
Amongſt happy Lovers we'l Play,
Ah Charon! make haſt with your Ferry,
Row hard, and I'le double your Pay.

sp.l: Irene we'l part no more—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Why do you pauſe upon't? he in his Madneſs ſhews
His laſting hate to me, and Love to her;
Revenge is rous'd again by Jealouſie,
And now I wiſh him Dead; Paſſions in me
Like Tides in ſome great Rivers, flow not in,
But firſt in heaps of Water take their view,
Then Roar, then tumble in Mountains of Sea,
Devouring Shores almoſt as quick as thought;
So now your times are come.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: I do rejoyce—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Your joy ſhall be but ſhort, pull Slaves!

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Hold Doggs!—

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Synan! how's this? dare you controul our orders?

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Not but by his; whom you your ſelf obey.
Our Mighty Sultan ſaw and pitty'd him.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: Oh I am loſt.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: No, Madam, I am ſo without your Mercy;
And 'tis 'gainſt me alone his Rage is bent,
For thus deluding him about Irene:
But ſave my Life ſince for your ſake I did it.

sp.speaker: Caliſt.
sp.l: No Synan, if thy Fate depends on me,
Thou muſt expect a dreadful Deſtiny.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: I ſee my Deaths inevitable now!
But I am glad my life does Ranſome yours.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: You cannot give us life, in them we die.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: That Death will but continue till they wake.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: How wake! my Lord! do not deſpiſe our griefs.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: 'Tis but a ſleepy potion, which they took,
Which I prepar'd to ſave them from Caliſta.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, you grieve without a cauſe
For fair Irene's not dead; This noble Baſſa.
Who knows no falſhood ſayes it.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Irene is living Sir.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ay, but She's angry,
She won't ſpeak one word to poor Thomazo.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Sir! ſhe's a ſleep!

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah do not wake her then!
Huſht! huſht! no noiſe, I pray let her ſleep—
She will be pleas'd anon—ſteale ſoftly out—
Softly—ſoftly—do not wake her for the world.
She's Dreaming now of poor Thmazo's love.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: I muſt admire the wayes of providence,
That ſtrangely thus by wicked mens deſigns,
Does oft protect the juſt—your Chancellor
To fortify his greatneſs in our Court
Has caus'd your being here, where you are ſafe,
Which elſe you con'd not be in our next ſtorm:
For then the Town's betray'd: The General
Has promis'd to march out with all his Souldiers,
And there's a Royal Half-moon Banner ſent
To th' Chancellor which will protect his houſe—

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: Good my Lord,
Let not the Prince hear this but by degrees,
His Brother and his Country's loſs will be
A Greif his worthy mind will hardly bare,
Shou'd he recover this which now aſſaults him.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: My Lord, you freely ſhall command this place
Whilſt I have any Breath to give that power,
And after that, you ſafely may rely—
Upon our Sultans friendſhip to the Prince,
Which I dare ſay is reall: But I muſt
Make haſt and meet that Death now ſtays for me.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: My Lord! I hope much better.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: No, my Lord!
Our Sultan's Frowns are Mortal; they'r met by this
To be ſpectators of my Tragedy.
Carry the Ladies in—when I am dead—
May you, my Lord, and all your Friends be happy.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: My Lord! farewell; may Heav'n preſerve
You ſtill—
But yet I fear he's loſt: Vertue on Earth
Is like ſome wholeſome Herb o're grown with Hemlock,
There is ſo little, men can hardly find it,
And all that uſe it are unfortunate—

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Theoph. Chancellor, Cardinal, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: This Information puzles my belief,
I ſooner ſhou'd have doubted my own Faith
Then Prince Thomazo's—ſure it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The things too evident for any doubt;
Hot ſpur'd Ambition in a Young mans breaſt
Ne're boyles at a Crime wou'd give it Checque.

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: But ſure the world muſt end, when Crimes like theſe
Are boldly Acted by the beſt of men;
Vertue has ſpent her utmoſt ſtock on Earth;—
Vertue, that Cement of the World, grows looſe,
Then Nature ſure muſt ſhake into its Chaos.
Irene to turn a Strumpet, did Amaze me!
Though ſhe's a Woman—but for Prince Thomazo
To make a baſe Revolt, is Miraculous.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: What can an Emperor, bounded and ty'd
By Laws, Act more than I already have—
But Heav'n and all things elſe conſpire our Ruin,
What can we then more but reſolve to Die;
Story ſhall never ſay I did neglect
My perſonal Duty to the very laſt.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: No, Mighty Sir, had the Revolted Prince,
And others of his Faction, but bin faithful,
You might have ſhin'd in Hiſtory, as great,
As does that Conſtantine who firſt Raign'd here.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Heav'n ſtrangely brings its great Decrees about
A Conſtantine, whoſe Mothers name was Helena,
Began this Empire: The Biſhop of this See
Was Theodotius then, ſo all are new,
Both, and State muſt ſink in the ſame names
As founded them; but let Heavens will be done.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Diſpair not Mighty Sir; the ways of Heav'n
Are paſt all finding out, who knows but you
May give a new beginning to this Empire
By driving back this faithleſs Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I for my ſubjects ſakes, perhaps could wiſh it,
Though for my ſelf a worthy death is beſt;
Which I have ſought from Mahomets own hand
By ſingle fight; but that he baſely waves
With Crowds of bleeding ſlaves he ſnatches glory,
Which flyes from me, who court it ſtill in perſon.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Sir I am come once more to ask our Pay,
Which, if deny'd, we preſently will March.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Now it begins to work!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Do as you pleaſe,
My ſubjects obſtinate to all entreaties,
Deny me their ſupplies; and I'm reſolv'd
Rather to periſh with them, then extend
My Regal pow'r beyond its uſual bounds:
Blinded they are, and blinded let them be,
Since they love Gold beyond themſelves and me.

sp.speaker: Juſtin.
sp.l: Bare witneſs all, that 'tis no fault of mine
This Empire ſinkes: I could have propt it yet;
And with this ſingle Arm ſuſtain'd it's weight,
Had not affronts upon affronts at firſt
Diſarm'd me of the power to wiſh your good;
But I'le not ſtay to bury all my glory
Under your mighty ruines; no, my Sword,
When you are nothing but the name of Prince,
Shall give me the full power of being ſo—

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Sir; will you patiently endure this ſlight!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Let him, and all the world grow inſolent;
It ſhall not move my rage: My Brothers Crimes
Have ſtupify'd my Anger.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Mighty Sir;
The perdues do fly in the Turks advance
As if they did intend a general Storm.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: All that dare not be Slaves, now follow me,
To certain Death, or glorious Victorie.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Dorello! ſure I'm deluded ſtill
And this I feel's another ſort of madneſs,
Is it not ſo, Dorello?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: No, my Lord;
Your cauſe of joy is ſollid, like thoſe Cares,
Whoſe unexpected ſounds, diſtemper'd you.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Am I then known, and in the Turkiſh Camp,
Yet free from Chaines? and does Irene ſtill live?
Nay, live for Prince Thomazo! this, Dorello,
My ſickly fancy wou'd perſwade is true.

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: For all theſe mighty Bleſſings, next to Heaven,
We owe our thanks toth' noble Eunuch Baſſa,
I wiſh his ſafety were as firm as ours.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Thanks to that hearty wiſh, and ſo it is;
See there the head that lately threaten'd mine.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Oh wonderful! Caliſta's head cut off!

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Ay noble Prince! our Sultan has deceiv'd us;
But to our ſatisfaction, for juſt now
Mounted upon a Throne in full aſſembly,
He did expoſe this Beauty to our view,
Seeming to glory in ſo rich a Jewel.
And had his praiſe Eccho'd back by us:
Then Beckon'd me, I went and kneel'd before him,
Thinking my ſelf a Victim to her Triumph,
And ſhe believ'd it too, for big with joy,
Her Eyes roll'd Grace to all; but ſcornes on me,
When in her height of Pride, one ſudden blow
Given by the Sultans Sword, took off her Head
So quick, ſhe cou'd not ſhreek one Pray'r for Mercy:
Then throwing me the Head—cry'd, Synan take it,
And ſmiling, bid us ſee, how much he valu'd
True Glory above Beauty—but the Storm
Will preſently begin, and I muſt thither,
And be an Actor in this Scene of Fate
Which will Create our Sultan Emperor.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Are you aſſur'd my Lord the Town will yield?

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Nothing more certain Sir, the Town's betray'd,
But Heav'n has ſo contriv'd that you are ſafe:
Farewell moſt noble Lords; if I am ſlain—
Think of me—If I live, I'm ſtill your Servant.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Dorello, 'tis not for us to live
Beyond our Princes Ruin. No, Brother,
Thomazo's Love and Fortune ſhall give way
When's Honour, or your ſafety is in queſtion;
Come Friends, let's once again Enter the Town,
And leave the Ladies here, they'l ſtill be ſafe,
What e're becomes of that, or of our lives,
Though Dead in them, ſome part of us ſurvives.

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Theophilus, and Attendants with Swords drawn, They paſs over the Stage in haſt, great Clamors and Noiſe.

div.stage: Trumpets and Drums beat a Battle.

stage.hi: Enter Chancellor, Lorenzo, and Michael, like Turks above.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: The ſport's begun, that noiſe which dreadful ſounds
To others Ears, to mine ſeems ſprightly Muſick.
Day breaks apace, as ſoon as we perceive
The Town is taken, hang the Banner out.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Shall we admit of ſuch as ſeek Protection?

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: No, not the Emperor himſelf ſhall enter;
Let them e'en take their Chance.
Oh, that was brave!
sp.stage: Cries, and running o're the ſtage, all's loſt, all's loſt.
sp.l: Hang out the Banner ſtrait, the Town's our own.

stage.hi: The Banner hung out; Enter Chriſtians, drove in by Turks. Enter Emperor, Theoph. &c. Who make ſtrong Fight by giving way. Enter Thomazo and Dorello Fighting, and driving off the Turks.

sp.speaker: Lorenz.
sp.l: See there! the Prince Thomazo and Dorello
Are Fighting on this ſide.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: I'm glad of that,
This forfeits all his favour with the Turk,
And 'tis not in his Pow'r to ſave the Town.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Brother, your Loyalty does bring a joy
Beyond what Victory it ſelf wou'd do.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Ah Royal Sir, there is no time to talk,
Our Men can never hold the ground we gain'd;
Were but your Perſon ſafe, I wou'd not Care.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: 'Tis ſafe whilſt Guarded by your Noble Sword,
And mine I hope ſhall prove a Guard to yours.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis in vain to hope to keep the Town:
Then take this time to ſave your ſelf by Flight,
Whilſt I make Head againſt the Entring Turks.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How Brother, Fly! No, it ſhall ne're be ſaid
That I ſurviv'd a loſs ſo great, as is
So brave a Brother, and an Empire too.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Sir, be not obſtinate! but ſee a Flag.
That ſpeaks Protection to the Chancellor,
Open your Gates my Lord, and take but in
Your Emperor and Theophilas; ſuch a Deed
Will make Atonement now for all your Crimes.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I will not hold my Safety from a Villain.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: No Sir, conent your ſelf, you come not here;
Nor any perſon elſe—my Crimes, my Lord,
Are got above the puniſhment of Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Infamous Renegade—but the Noiſe
Calls loud for our aſſiſtance—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Come, Dorello,
Let's Keep him ſafe as long as e're we can—

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Blaſphemous Traytor, are thy Crimes ſo great?
Thou thinks the pow'rs above han't ſtrength to puniſh!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Talk not my Lord, I for your Daughters ſake
Will let you ſingly in, and ſave your life.

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: No curſed Dog, I'd ſooner find my Death
From my own hand, then owe my life to thee.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Nay, if you be ſo brisk, e'en take your Chance!
What inſolent Slaves are theſe?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Oh my good Lord!
Let me but find protection in your Houſe!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: Alas my Lord, your Eminence on foot!
'Tis a great way to Rome; you had beſt make haſt,
Spare Complements to me—you have my leave—

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: My Lord! mock not my miſery.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: You'l be belated truly, wanting Horſes,
My Duty to his Holineſs, and tell him,
I've ended now this long continuing Schiſme
To his own hearts Content!

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Impudent Traytor!

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: See ſee, the Cardinal has loſt his Gout—

stage.hi: Enter Emperor, Thomazo, Theoph. Dorello, and Guards Fighting before the Turks. Emperor falls Dead.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Oh Heavens! the Emperor's Slain, preſerve his Body.

stage.hi: They Fight. Enter Synan, who fighting falls. They are going to Kill him. Thomazo prevents it—

sp.l: Accept your Life from Prince Thomazo Sir,
As part of recompence for all your favour Sir.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Moſt noble Prince, perſiſt not thus in vain
To ſtop the Current of our Victory,
Which will at laſt flow o're, and drown you all;
You, and thoſe you ſhall chuſe, ſhall on my honour,
Be ſafe from either Death or Slavery.—

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I've nothing now to fight for, but my ſelf,
Since this brave Prince is Slain, therefore I yield
To be a Priſoner to Noble Synan.

sp.speaker: Syna.
sp.l: Chriſtians, put up your Swords, this party ſhall
Continue as a guard about your perſon,
But that they may be ſafe, I will appoint
Some Janizaries that may joyne with them.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your Favours all are large!

sp.speaker: Syna.
sp.l: Lord Chancellor,
The Sultan does require your perſon ſhou'd, ſhou'd,
Be brought before him ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Chanc.
sp.l: With haſt I'le fly
To Kiſs the Foot of our great Emperour.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: What various changes have our miſeries?

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: 'Tis better ſure we had for ever ſlept
Then onely wak't to a more grievous Death.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: See yonder! how the Flames aſcend the Skies,
Seeming to melt the Heavens.

sp.speaker: Iren.
sp.l: O ſad ſight!
This is the Prince Thomazo's Funeral Pile,
And I ungrateful, I don't leap into't,
But I'le not long ſurvive thee, noble Prince,
For in a Flood of Teares I'le drown my ſelf,
Thus from two warning Elements we'l meet
Above; yet keep an everlaſting Peace!

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: I yet could Chide, methinks their gallantry
That cou'd expoſe both us and them to ruine,
In ſuch a needleſs danger as they ſought.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: No 'twas their duty lead them to the fight,
And I do love Thomazo's flame too well,
To wiſh him ſafe with loſs of any honour,
Though to revive from Death, and meet him well,
Then ſtraight again to loſe him, ſeems ſevere.

sp.speaker: Ʋdox.
sp.l: Ha! what viſion's this!

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Do I ſee thee alive, and vertuous both?
Can Heav'n bring joy after theſe fatal loſſes!
Irene, our Prince is ſlain and Country loſt.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: Did not the thoughts of that ſuſpend my joy,
To ſee Thomazo and your ſelf alive,
I ſcarcely ſhould be able to ſupport it.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: Great Sir! the Sultan has commanded me,
To greet you with this ſtile—King of Morea;
For with that Kingdom he does now inveſt you,
Under the tribute of an Annual Horſe.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Your Princes's ſoul's as large as is his Empire,
And I with grateful thanks receive the guift.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: That action which I fear'd would raiſe his anger
Increas'd but his eſteeme—He ſaid, you could
Have found no better way to perfect glory
Then this laſt act of fighting for your Brother:
And it has ſtrengthen'd much his Friendſhip to you.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: How ſhall I e're expreſs my gratitude
For all theſe Mighty Favours he beſtowes.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: The riches in the Town are found prodigious;
Though baſely they deny'd their Prince aſſiſtance;
For which 600000. Thouſand Souls and more
Forever muſt into—Captivity—
As a juſt reward for their Diſobedience!
Only he does permit you ſhall ſet free
Ten thouſand of ſuch Perſons you beſt like;
The Chancellor and ſome few other Traitors
He only does except: For they muſt die
A juſt example to all future times;
He further does intend a Noble preſent
For this fair Lady; whom he dares not ſee.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: He is a Prince of ſuch a mighty Soul;
Vertues in him contend for Victory,
And each of them in turn do gain a Triumph.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: The Execution's doing on the Traytors!
Step but a broad and you may ſee the Train.
I'le go and cleer, and ſtand—

sp.speaker: Theop.
sp.l: Fame certainly does ſpread abro de
'Twas you the Sultan kill'd.

sp.speaker: Irene.
sp.l: That errour does ariſe becauſe we were
Ne're ſeen by any perſon but the Mutes;
The Sultan, and two Baſſa's, ſince we came,
And Fame does ſtill report I was his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Let fame be ſtill a Lyar, my Irene,
And ſay, 'tis thou art Dead, ſo I can thus
Admire thy living Beauties—but let's go
And ſee the Sultans juſtice upon Traitors—

stage.hi: The Scene a great Number of Dead and Dying men in ſeveral manner of Death's. The Chancellor, Lorenzo, and Michael Empal'd.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Make way there! Make way.

stage.hi: Enter Synan and Mutes, Thomazo, Dorello, & the reſt.

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: What a ſad ſight is this?

sp.speaker: Dorel.
sp.l: This is a ſevere extenſion of his power.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: This Turkiſh way of rule threatens the world,
As if their Creſcent would at laſt be full,
And rule it all.

sp.speaker: Synan.
sp.l: This is the way to govern:
Severity, not Mercy, ſtrengthens power.
See there your Chancellor and his two Scribes.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I pitty them, though they deſerv'd far worſe,
For ruining their Country, whoſe ſad Fate,
We during life ſhall Mourn, yet in our Tales
We muſt your Vertue, and the Sultans praiſe,
And Monuments of Thanks for ever raiſe.
